Once an ordinary jewel, it became a prison for her spirit after her death, transforming into a source of both power and corruption. The Heartstone was kept in the palace, where Aeliraâ€™s presence subtly protected the city and comforted Tharion, even as it reminded him of his guilt and loss. **Why it was moved:** During Tharionâ€™s coronation, Azarothâ€™s agents and the Severin cult orchestrated the removal of the Heartstone to weaken the cityâ€™s defenses and sever the last link to the old magic. At the time, Tharion was so consumed by regret and psychological damage that he posed no real threat to their control. However, they saw the Heartstone as a latent danger: if Tharionâ€™s will ever recovered, or if Aeliraâ€™s influence through the stone grew stronger, it could become a source of resistance or even a rallying point for the old magic. To prevent this, they manipulated Tharion into believing that keeping the Heartstone was unhealthy and that letting go was necessary for his own well-being and the cityâ€™s future. In truth, its removal further isolated Tharion and marked the beginning of the cityâ€™s decline. To achieve this, they manipulated Tharion psychologicallyâ€”convincing him that holding onto the Heartstone was unhealthy, that it kept him trapped in grief and regret, and that letting go was necessary for his own well-being and for the future of the city. They preyed on his guilt, suggesting that Aeliraâ€™s fate was his fault and that her memory was a burden he must release. In truth, this act further isolated Tharion, deepened his sorrow, and marked the beginning of the cityâ€™s decline. **Current Location:** Eventually, the Heartstone is lost and later found in the Citadel (Grave Horde).Siania can get through, but anyone else would be turned awayâ€”or worse. ### **1. Grand Conjunction Ritual (Celestial-Linked Symbolic Invocation)** **Magic Used:** - **Starlight-Infused Symbolic Invocation** (amplified by planetary alignment) - **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** (on a massive scale) - **Aether-Linked Object Transformation** (to trap life force in crystal) **How it works:** The mage prepares a vast ritual, inscribing symbols and aligning objects to the rare conjunction of all planets. The celestial event acts as a magical amplifier, allowing him to channel immense power through his symbols. At the moment of conjunction, he uses the ritual to rewrite the fate of the armyâ€”erasing their future and binding their life force into crystal using aetheric transformation. **Effect:** - The armyâ€™s life force is ripped from their bodies and sealed in crystal, their histories rewritten so they are forever trapped at that moment. - The mage absorbs the released energy, achieving immortality. --- ### **2. Life Force Binding and Immortality (Aether-Linked Object Transformation + Bloodline Control)** **Magic Used:** - **Aether-Linked Object Transformation** (to bind and store life force) - **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** (with death or time spirits, to maintain immortality) - **Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control** (to command the crystal and its power) **How it works:** The mage uses aetheric magic to bind the stolen life force into a crystal matrix, making it a reservoir of power. He forms a metaphysical contract with spirits of death or time, promising them continued influence in exchange for his own unending life. He also learns the true name of the crystal and the ritual, allowing him to command and draw on its power at will. **Effect:** - The mage cannot die as long as the crystal remains intact and the contract is unbroken. - He can draw on the trapped life force for magical power, healing, or to extend his influence. --- ## **Azarothâ€™s Magic: Mechanisms of Bloodline Enslavement and Temple Corruption** ### **1. Seduction and Faustian Bargains** **Magic Used:** - **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** - **Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control** **How it works:** Azaroth seduces the guardians and Tharion with promises of protection and salvation, but every bargain is a trap. By invoking ancient names and forging metaphysical contracts, he binds the guardians, the bloodline, and the templeâ€™s fate to his will. These contracts are enforced by spirits and cannot be broken without dire cost. **Effect:** The royal family and temple leaders are compelled to serve Azaroth, their agency eroded by the weight of broken promises and spiritual compulsion. Every attempt to resist only tightens the magical noose. --- ### **2. Ritual Betrayal and Soul Harvesting** **Magic Used:** - **Starlight-Infused Symbolic Invocation** (amplified by the Great Conjunction) - **Aether-Linked Object Transformation** - **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** **How it works:** During the Great Battle, Azaroth uses the rare planetary alignment to supercharge his ritual. He inscribes symbols that, when activated by the conjunction, rewrite the fate of the crystalline armyâ€”harvesting their life force and transforming them into crystal statues. The land itself is cursed, and the cityâ€™s decline begins. **Effect:** The templeâ€™s power source is now a prison of souls, and the land is tainted. The trauma of this event is woven into the bloodlineâ€™s memory, ensuring generational guilt and weakness. --- ### **3. Generational Manipulation and Cult Control** **Magic Used:** - **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** - **Spirit-Assisted Object Linking** - **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** **How it works:** The Severin cult, acting as Azarothâ€™s agents, manipulates marriages, alliances, and disasters. The Severin Sigil, a magical mark, appears at every turning point, reinforcing the cultâ€™s influence. The bloodline is linked to the temple and the crystal, and their history is repeatedly rewritten to ensure loyalty, confusion, and dependency. **Effect:** The bloodline is weakened, their sense of self and purpose eroded. The cultâ€™s power grows, and the templeâ€™s original mission is lost beneath layers of magical and psychological manipulation. --- ### **4. Architectural and Ritual Corruption** **Magic Used:** - **Starlight-Infused Symbolic Invocation** - **Aether-Linked Object Transformation** - **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** **How it works:** The templeâ€™s architecture is physically and magically defiled. New, jagged glyphs are carved through the old sacred patterns, twisting protective and harmonious symbols into snares and sources of torment. The crystal at the heart of the temple is transformed into a nexus of malice and dimensional instability, channeling energy from the city and amplifying Azarothâ€™s control. **Effect:** The temple becomes a living engine of oppression, its beauty weaponized to inflict pain and reinforce the bloodlineâ€™s bondage. The crystalâ€™s presence dominates, and the very air is charged with malice and the threat of dimensional collapse. --- ### **5. Psychological and Political Enslavement** **Magic Used:** - **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** - **Spirit-Assisted Object Linking** - **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** - **Subtle Mind and Will Control (possibly via enchanted advisors and artifacts)** **How it works:** Azaroth and his cult use a combination of magical compulsion, psychological manipulation, and political pressure to keep the bloodline and temple leadership in line. Advisors and councillors are enchanted or contracted to enforce Azarothâ€™s will, and the royal family is isolated, gaslit, and forced into submission. **Effect:** The bloodline is trapped not just by magic, but by a web of fear, guilt, and social control. Even their memories and desires are suspect, and every attempt at rebellion is anticipated and neutralized. --- ## **How This Magic Shapes the Royal Family and Temple** - **The bloodline is metaphysically and psychologically bound to the temple and the crystal.** Their fates are linked; as long as the bloodline endures, so does Azarothâ€™s control. - **The templeâ€™s rituals, architecture, and very purpose are corrupted.** What was once a place of harmony and protection is now a nexus of pain, malice, and dimensional instability. - **Generational trauma and manipulation ensure the bloodlineâ€™s weakness and dependency.** Each generation is more isolated, more confused, and more easily controlled. - **The Severin cult acts as both magical enforcers and political jailers.** Their sigil is a constant reminder of Azarothâ€™s power and the bloodlineâ€™s helplessness. - **Breaking the cycle requires not just magical power, but healing, forgiveness, and the restoration of true memory and purpose.** Sianiaâ€™s journey is as much about reclaiming her heritage and agency as it is about defeating Azarothâ€™s magic. --- **In summary:** Azarothâ€™s magic is a tapestry of soul-binding, history rewriting, ritual corruption, and psychological domination, all anchored in the templeâ€™s architecture and the bloodlineâ€™s fate. The only way to break it is to unravel each threadâ€”restoring memory, severing links, and reclaiming the templeâ€™s original harmony. --- ### **Summary of the Mageâ€™s Magic:** - **Celestial-Linked Symbolic Invocation:** Harnessing planetary conjunctions to amplify ritual magic. - **Aether-Linked Object Transformation:** Trapping and storing life force in crystal. - **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps:** Erasing or altering the fate of entire armies and bloodlines. - **Spirit-Assisted Object Linking:** Binding himself to the temple and its bloodline. - **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting:** Bargaining with powerful spirits for immortality and control. - **Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control:** Commanding the crystal and the templeâ€™s power by knowing their true names. --- **In essence:** He is a master of **ritual, celestial, and aetheric magics**, using rare cosmic events, soul-binding, and history rewriting to achieve immortality and dominion. His control over the templeâ€™s bloodline is maintained through magical linking, rewriting, and spirit contractsâ€”making him nearly impossible to defeat by ordinary means. [[Memories]] [[Azarothâ€™s Magic: Mechanisms of Bloodline Enslavement and Temple Corruption]] [[Grand Conjunction Ritual (Celestial-Linked Symbolic Invocation]] [[Life Force Binding and Immortality (Aether-Linked Object Transformation + Bloodline Control)]] [[**Azarothâ€™s Magic: Mechanisms of Bloodline Enslavement and Temple Corruption**]] [[Ritual Betrayal and Soul Harvesting]] [[Generational Manipulation and Cult Control]] [[Architectural and Ritual Corruption]] [[Psychological and Political Enslavement]] [[How This Magic Shapes the Royal Family and Temple]]<h2>Agara The Dawn Empress</h2> - **Dawn Empress:** A figure from the past who fought with two blades. Sianian only has one she gets the second on here! Agara (Agamar/The Dawn Empress) was the former Queen and Enchantress of Talin, a legendary figure known as the Dawn Empress for her unique fighting style with two hereditary blades. Her reign was marked by both magical prowess and martial skill, but her life took a tragic turn when she was betrayed by her Sadaarkian husband, leading to her exile in the harsh Azeroth Desert. During her hasty departure, she was forced to leave one of the two hereditary blades behind in Talin, a loss that symbolized her diminished power and broken legacy. Now, as the keeper of a sanctuary in the desert and a historian of her bloodline Agara (Agamar/The Dawn Empress) was the last true Queen and Enchantress of Talin, her reign ending in a legendary exodus. When her Sadaarkian husband's corruption became undeniable - his people's alien magic poisoning the temples, their meticulous breeding programs creating children designed to serve [House Vestergaard and others] - she saw the terrible pattern. The Sadaaki were systematically damaging native magic, making it accessible only through advantageous family lines while sinking others into obscurity through corrupted genetics. But they needed House Te'Niriania's ancient elven-human bloodline intact - the key to the temple's power that couldn't be altered, only controlled. In her final act as queen, Agara led many of the magical creatures from Talin into the desert - griffons and temple serpents, moon foxes and storm hawks, and the gentle, pony-sized spiders (whose absence is why spiders are now vilified and feared) - understanding they'd be twisted into tools of oppression if left behind. This grand procession birthed her dual legacy: to some, the "Witch-Queen" who abandoned her people; to others, a sleeping protector who preserved Talin's true heart. Now, from her hidden sanctuary, she watches as Siania - a direct descendant of her own Ne' Tiri'ania bloodline - approaches her trial, while the city's children still whisper of the day their queen walked into the sandstorms, leading their soul away to safety. she made her fateful choice. Not with blades (for she left one behind as warning and promise), but with creatures. In her final act as queen, she led every last magical being from Talin into the desert - griffons and temple serpents, moon foxes and storm hawks - understanding they'd be corrupted or destroyed if left behind. This grand procession birthed her dual legacy: to some, the "Witch-Queen" who abandoned the city, stealing souls; to others, a sleeping savior, destined to return when Talin faces its darkest hour, heralded by the beasts she saved. Now, from her hidden sanctuary, she waits, knowing Siania may be the key to awakening that promise, reclaiming both blade and legacy, and proving whether Agara was a destroyer or Talin's last, best hope. **Connections:** - Kin to Siania, mentor to the spiders. - Cursed/Exiled and Betrayed by her lover/to be consort a member of the Sadaarki and the Severin cult. - Her pact with Siania and the spiders is key to the cityâ€™s liberation.<h2>Spirit-Assisted Object Linking</h2> ### 1. **Spirit-Assisted Object Linking** _Counters using magical links and spirits to disrupt or redirect other magics._ - **To counter Symbol-Activated Metal Consumption:** Link the metal inside the user to a heavy anchor, draining or redirecting the magical effect away from the user. - **To counter Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control:** Link the target spirit or force to a mundane object, restricting its movement or ability to act. - **To counter Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps:** Link the rewritten object to its original self, causing the magical properties to revert to normal. - **To counter Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting:** Link the blood symbol to an absorbent object, physically and magically erasing the symbol. - **To counter Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting:** Link the spiritâ€™s contract to a physical trigger, such as a bell, so that when the bell rings, the contract is suspended. --- ### 2. **Symbol-Activated Metal Consumption** _Counters by activating metals with specific symbols to disrupt or erase other magics._ - **To counter Spirit-Assisted Object Linking:** Swallow copper with a â€œspirit banishmentâ€ symbol; when activated, it emits a pulse that drives away the spirit maintaining the link. - **To counter Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control:** Swallow lead with a â€œsilenceâ€ symbol; when activated, it muffles all spoken words, preventing the use of true names. - **To counter Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps:** Swallow tin with a â€œreveal truthâ€ symbol; when activated, it dispels all false histories in the area. - **To counter Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting:** Swallow gold with a â€œpurifyâ€ symbol; when activated, it neutralizes all blood-based magic in the area. - **To counter Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting:** Swallow iron with a â€œbreak contractâ€ symbol; when activated, it severs all magical agreements in the area. --- ### 3. **Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control** _Counters by using true names and promises to command, dismiss, or revert magical effects._ - **To counter Spirit-Assisted Object Linking:** Learn the true name of the spirit maintaining the link and command it to return home, breaking the link. - **To counter Symbol-Activated Metal Consumption:** Learn the true name of the symbol or metal and command it to become inert, ending the effect. - **To counter Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps:** Learn the true name of the objectâ€™s original history and command it to return to that state. - **To counter Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting:** Learn the true name of the blood used and command it to return to the mageâ€™s body, erasing the symbol. - **To counter Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting:** Learn the true name of the contracted spirit and command it to forget the contract. --- ### 4. **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** _Counters by rewriting the history of objects, people, or contracts to erase or alter magical effects._ - **To counter Spirit-Assisted Object Linking:** Stamp the linked object so it was never linked, erasing the connection. - **To counter Symbol-Activated Metal Consumption:** Stamp the metal so it was never engraved with the symbol, removing the effect. - **To counter Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control:** Stamp the contract or spirit so the promise was never made, breaking the bond. - **To counter Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting:** Stamp the ground or object so the blood symbol was never drawn. - **To counter Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting:** Stamp the contract document so it was never signed, erasing the agreement. --- ### 5. **Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting** _Counters by drawing blood symbols that absorb, ground, or void other magical effects._ - **To counter Spirit-Assisted Object Linking:** Draw a blood symbol on the linked object that grounds magical connections, dissolving the link. - **To counter Symbol-Activated Metal Consumption:** Draw a blood symbol on the ground that absorbs all shield or enhancement effects in the area. - **To counter Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control:** Draw a blood symbol that â€œseals all namesâ€ in the area, making it impossible to use true names for magic. - **To counter Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps:** Draw a blood symbol on the object that â€œanchors true history,â€ making it immune to rewriting. - **To counter Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting:** Draw a blood symbol that â€œvoids all promisesâ€ in the area, making all magical contracts powerless. --- ### 6. **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** _Counters by contracting spirits to guard, intercept, or erase other magical effects._ - **To counter Spirit-Assisted Object Linking:** Contract a guardian spirit to protect an object from outside magic, blocking any attempt to link it. - **To counter Symbol-Activated Metal Consumption:** Contract a spirit to â€œdevour all magical shieldsâ€ within a certain range, eating the effect as soon as it activates. - **To counter Secret-Name and Promise-Based Force Control:** Contract a spirit to â€œintercept all callsâ€ to a specific force or spirit, blocking the magic from working. - **To counter Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps:** Contract a spirit to â€œguard the true pastâ€ of an object, undoing any magical rewriting. - **To counter Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting:** Contract a spirit to â€œcleanse all blood magicâ€ in the area, erasing the symbol. ### 1. **Starlight-Infused Symbolic Invocation** _How it works:_ Mages draw symbols on objects or in the air, but the symbols only activate when exposed to starlight. The starlight acts as a magical catalyst, charging the symbols and releasing their effects. The more direct and pure the starlight, the stronger the magic. --- ### 2. **Tide-Synchronized Spirit Bargaining** _How it works:_ Mages summon and negotiate with ocean spirits, but the strength and willingness of the spirits depend on the current tide. High tide brings powerful, eager spirits; low tide brings weaker, reluctant ones. The mageâ€™s promises and contracts are only valid as long as the tide remains in the same phase. --- ### 3. **Mist-Channelled Memory Rewriting** _How it works:_ Mages use natural mist as a medium to rewrite memoriesâ€”either their own or othersâ€™. The mist must physically touch the target, and the new memory only lasts as long as the mist lingers. When the mist dissipates, the original memory returns. --- ### 4. **Aether-Linked Object Transformation** _How it works:_ Mages tap into invisible aether currents that flow through all things. By linking an object to a specific aether current, they can temporarily transform its properties (for example, making stone as light as air or wood as hard as steel). The transformation lasts only while the aether link is maintained. --- ### 5. **Combined Promise and Elemental Channeling** _How it works:_ Mages make a binding promise to a natural element (like fire, water, wind, or earth), and in return, the element grants them a portion of its power. The mage must uphold their end of the promise (such as never letting a fire go out or always returning water to a river), or the element withdraws its power and may even turn against the mage. ### To conjure a whirlpool that can pull down a fleet of ships (using metaphysical bargaining): 1. **Attune to the Tides:** The practitioner enter altered state at the moment of high tide, aligning their spirit with the rhythm and consciousness of the ocean. 2. **Open the Bridge:** Through ritual movement, chanting, or breathwork, the practitioner opens themselves as a conduit between the physical world and the realm of oceanic spirits. 3. **Offer Service or Exchange:** the practitioner offers a metaphysical serviceâ€”such as carrying a message between worlds, sharing a vision, or allowing the ocean spirits to experience the world through their senses for a time. The practitioner might also offer a portion of their own life energy, a memory, or a vow to act as the oceanâ€™s voice in the mortal realm. 4. **Seal the Pact:** The agreement is sealed not with objects, but with a merging of intent and will. The practitioner and the spirits share a moment of unity, and the spirits accept the practitionerâ€™s offering as sufficient. 5. **Channel the Power:** Acting as a living bridge, the practitioner channels the spiritsâ€™ will into the physical world, shaping the waters into a vast, spiraling whirlpool that pulls down the fleet. 6. **Maintain the Connection:** The whirlpool persists as long as the practitioner can sustain the bridge and uphold their metaphysical promise. If the practitioner falters or the connection is broken, the spirits withdraw, and the whirlpool dissipates. ### **Implications of Metaphysical Bargaining Magic** **1. Spirits Are Realm-Bound:** Oceanic (or other) spirits are powerful, but their direct influence is limited to their own realm. They cannot easily cross into the mortal world or act upon it without a living bridgeâ€”a practitioner who can open the way. **2. Mortals as Essential Bridges:** Practitioners are not just spellcasters, but vital intermediaries. Only through their altered states, rituals, and willingness to serve as conduits can spirits manifest their will in the physical world. This makes practitioners both valuable and vulnerable. **3. Metaphysical Exchange, Not Material:** The bargains are not about gold, pearls, or physical offerings, but about experience, memory, energy, or service. The practitioner might let a spirit see through their eyes, feel mortal emotions, or even borrow a fragment of their life force. **4. Ancient Pacts and Magical Laws:** There are old, binding magical laws or pacts that prevent spirits from crossing realms unassisted. These could be the result of ancient wars, betrayals, or cosmic treaties. Only by working with mortalsâ€”who are not bound by these same rulesâ€”can spirits circumvent these restrictions. (this can come as cost to both humans and the entity if caught!) **5. Spirit Realm Politics and Intrigue:** Because access to the mortal world is so precious, spirits may compete, scheme, or even wage subtle wars for the favor of powerful practitioners. Some spirits might try to sabotage othersâ€™ bargains, or tempt practitioners into breaking their pacts. **6. Mortal Agency and Risk:** Practitioners wield great power, but at a cost. If they break their metaphysical promise, they might lose their abilities, suffer spiritual backlash, or become targets for vengeful spirits. The balance of power is delicate and always shifting. --- **Storytelling Possibilities:** - A practitioner caught between rival ocean spirits, each offering different visions or powers. - A secret society of practitioners who police the boundaries between realms, preventing reckless bargains. - A spirit war spilling into the mortal world when a practitionerâ€™s bridge is hijacked or corrupted. - Ancient texts or prophecies about the original pacts that bound the spirits, and the consequences of breaking them. ---- ### **1. Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** - **How it helps:** The enchantress can use a magic stamp to rewrite the dark mageâ€™s memory or the palaceâ€™s â€œmemoryâ€ so that Ashâ€™s presence is erased. For example, after Ash passes through a corridor, the enchantress stamps the wall or a nearby object, rewriting its history so that Ash was never seen or sensed there. This would make it impossible for the dark mage to track Ashâ€™s movements through psychic or magical meansâ€”at least for a short time. --- ### **2. Spirit-Assisted Object Linking** - **How it helps:** The enchantress can link doors, windows, or secret passages to a small, helpful spirit. When Ash approaches, the spirit quietly unlocks or opens the way, allowing Ash to move without making noise or leaving physical evidence. This is especially useful for bypassing magical locks or traps set by the dark mage. --- ### **3. Mist-Channelled Memory Rewriting** - **How it helps:** If there is natural or conjured mist in the palace, the enchantress can use it to temporarily rewrite the memories of any guards, magical wards, or even the dark mage himself. As Ash passes, the mist touches those who might notice him, making them forget they saw anything unusual. This effect lasts only as long as the mist lingers, so itâ€™s best for quick, stealthy movement. --- ### **4. Starlight-Infused Symbolic Invocation** - **How it helps:** If there is moonlight or starlight entering the palace, the enchantress could draw a symbol of â€œconcealmentâ€ or â€œshadowâ€ on Ash or on the walls. When touched by starlight, this symbol would cloak Ash in magical invisibility, at least in areas where the starlight reaches. --- ### **5. Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** - **How it helps:** The enchantress could form a quick pact with a local spirit of shadows or silence, promising a future service in exchange for the spiritâ€™s help in hiding Ashâ€™s presence from the dark mageâ€™s psychic senses. This would be risky, as breaking the promise could have consequences, but it might buy Ash precious time. --- ### **6. Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting** - **How it helps:** In a desperate moment, the enchantress could draw a blood symbol of â€œerasureâ€ or â€œsilenceâ€ on a door, wall, or even on Ash himself, making him undetectable to magical surveillance for a short period. This is taxing and dangerous, so it would be used only if absolutely necessary. --- ### **Tactical Approach for Ash and the Enchantress:** - **Primary:** Use **Personal History Rewriting with Magic Stamps** to erase Ashâ€™s presence from the palaceâ€™s and the dark mageâ€™s memory as he moves. - **Support:** Use **Spirit-Assisted Object Linking** to quietly open doors and bypass magical barriers. - **Supplement:** If available, use **Mist-Channelled Memory Rewriting** for quick, temporary cover, and **Starlight-Infused Symbolic Invocation** for magical concealment in moonlit areas. - **Emergency:** Resort to **Mutual-Promise Spirit Contracting** or **Blood-Drawn Symbolic Spellcasting** if Ash is about to be discovered or trapped. --- **Limitation:** As you noted, these magics are taxing for the human enchantress, especially if used repeatedly or for long periods. Ash must move quickly and efficiently, relying on the enchantressâ€™s magic only when absolutely necessary.~~Strikethrough Text~~<H1>Valerius - Political Calculus</H1> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>A Damaged but Valuable Ally:</h2>] Vestergaard arrives at House Kren as Siania's betrothed, but also as a rebel Lord Heir fleeing his own mother and the Order of Severin. This dual status is infinitely more useful to Valerius than if Vestergaard arrived simply as a rebel. By having Vestergaard betrothed to Siania, Valerius can leverage the marriage to secure a powerful alliance, binding House Vestergaard and House Kren together. This alliance strengthens his position politically and militarily. At the same time, Vestergaardâ€™s rebellion against his mother allows Valerius to pursue the deposition of Lady Vestergaard, which would restart vital trade routes and stabilize the realm. The marriage and rebellion together create a unique opportunity: Valerius can present himself as the architect of peace and order, while undermining Severinâ€™s influence. This scenario provides Valerius with both a political weapon and a path to reshape the balance of power â€” all while maintaining plausible deniability and protecting Sianiaâ€™s safety. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Value of the Loyalist Trackers (Jaro, Torren, Tarek):</h2>] Credibility & Legitimacy: They aren't just bodyguards; they are sianias friends & Ne'Tiriania loyalists from Fort Kezarak. Their presence vouches for Vestergaard's story and Siania's legitimacy. They confirm: - The clause exists (its with Vestergaard). - Siania's survival (initially) and her command to aid Vestergaard. - Their presence links Vestergaard's rebellion directly to the true Tirianian cause Siania represents, giving Valerius moral high ground. Military & Intelligence Asset: These are elite desert trackers and soldiers. They provide invaluable tactical insight into Fort Kezarak, Lucian military procedures, and desert warfare. They bolster Kren's forces. Smoothing Relations: As Siania's sworn warriors vouching for Vestergaard, they act as a crucial bridge between the traditionally antagonistic House Kren and the rebel Vestergaard heir. They mitigate suspicion and translate intent. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Valerius's Offer & Strategy:</h2>] Protection & Sanctuary: Valerius offers Vestergaard and his loyalists sanctuary within Kren territory, safeguarding them from his mother's hunters and Severin assassins. Political & Military Support: Valerius pledges Kren resources (gold, agents, soldiers) to support Vestergaard's bid to depose his mother and cleanse House Vestergaard of Severin. The Grand Bargain: Valerius outlines the plan Vestergaard and Siania devised, but now executed with Kren's power: 1. Controlled Exposure: Valerius uses Kren's network to strategically leak the clause and evidence of Lady Vestergaard's/Severin's plot to the Emperor and other Great Houses. He frames it as Kren uncovering a dire threat to the realm and the Emperor's own lineage (Siania's intended murder). 2. Positioning Vestergaard: Vestergaard is presented not as a rebel, but as the loyal Heir who discovered his mother's treason, acted to stop it (Eli's death framed as silencing a security breach), and fled to Kren for aid in preserving his house and serving the Crown by exposing the traitors. He denounces his mother and Severin. 3. Kren as Righteous Enforcer: House Kren positions itself as the defender of the realm's stability, the true Tirianian legacy (via Siania's loyalists), and the Emperor's interests (exposing the plot against his daughter and himself). 4. Deposing Lady Vestergaard: Kren-backed forces (potentially including elements of other outraged Houses) support Vestergaard in seizing control of his house, arresting/executing his mother and her Severin allies. 5. Rewards for Kren: Valerius secures: - A cleansed, grateful, and allied House Vestergaard under Darian. - Massive political capital for exposing the conspiracy and "saving" the realm. - Weakened Severin and Hyrach influence. - Leadership of a bloc of Houses united against Severin/Hyrach. - Vindication for his belief in Siania's potential and the old blood (her magic glimpsed, her loyalists proving her cause just). - Crucially: This happens without Siania present, minimizing immediate risk to her and allowing Lucius to potentially believe she is dead, preventing him from unleashing his full force preemptively. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Siania's Disappearance: A Strategic Necessity</h2>] [1. Lucius's Perception: The khamsin and the hunt provide the perfect cover. Lucius must believe Siania perished. If he knew she lived and was rallying support (via Vestergaard reaching Kren), he would see an existential threat and crush the rebellion with overwhelming force before it gains momentum. Her "death" buys time. 2. Siania's Path: Her journey to Agara/Oasis/Temple is separate but vital. It fulfills her mother's legacy, potentially unlocks ancient power/knowledge crucial for the long-term fight against Severin and reclaiming her birthright, and keeps her safe from immediate retribution. 3. Future Reunion: Her return, potentially wielding newfound power or legitimacy from Agara, can be a devastatingly powerful moment later, once the rebellion led by Kren and Vestergaard is already underway and has secured significant gains. It becomes a rallying cry, not an opening gambit easily crushed. :: Valerius Kren - Why Vestergaard Can Never Marry Siania (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Why Vestergaard Can Never Marry Siania:</h2>] The union between Vestergaard and Siania is inherently forbidden, not merely strategically inconvenient. The reasons are deeply rooted in the lore and the overarching conflict: (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Bloodline Purity: ] House Kren fiercely opposes the mixing of the Vestergaard and Ne'Tiriania bloodlines. It is believed that the convergence of these specific lineages would create an entity of immense, uncontrollable power, a conduit for a darkness neither possesses alone. This is not a matter of political preference but a fundamental principle for House Kren. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Severin's Engineered Match: ] The Order of Severin actively seeks this union, viewing the offspring as a means to amplify their influence and control. The marriage is not a natural alliance but a calculated manipulation to birth a being they can exploit. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Impending Darkness: ] The child born from this union is prophesied to be a catalyst for immense destruction. The genetic combination would result in a mutation, a being capable of unleashing chaos and darkness upon the realm. This is the core reason why Valerius and House Kren are vehemently against it. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Hunt Continues:] The fact that both Siania and Vestergaard are missing only delays Severin's plans; it does not negate them. The Order continues to hunt them, driven by their obsession with controlling the bloodlines and bringing about the prophesied darkness. Their separation is a temporary setback, not a victory. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>In Conclusion:</h2>] Vestergaard arriving at Kren without Siania, bearing the clause and accompanied by her loyalist trackers, is the optimal scenario for Valerius's coldly pragmatic plans. It allows him to: - Wage a proxy war against Severin and Lady Vestergaard under the guise of righteous intervention and preserving stability. - Install a powerful, indebted ally as Lord of House Vestergaard. - Massively increase House Kren's influence and lead an anti-Severin coalition. - Advance Siania's cause (via her loyalists and the exposure of the plot against her) without immediately provoking Lucius's full wrath, believing her dead. - He still needs to find Siannia as the figurehead of the revolution The ochre dust of the Rashaâ€™ni canyons might cloak Darian Vestergaard, but it couldnâ€™t smother the cold calculus unfolding in Talon. Valerius Kren received the coded confirmation â€“ Hawk sheltered, Ravens guard â€“ with a satisfaction quickly tempered by harsh reality. Vestergaard was safe, yes. A potent hidden weapon, absolutely. But he was only half the equation. The other half remained lost in the desert storm, and her absence was a gaping wound in Valeriusâ€™s meticulously laid plans. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Vestergaard: Asset, Not Answer</h2>] Hidden deep within the Rashaâ€™ni territory, Vestergaard existed in a state of suspended animation. Valerius ensured his safety and comfort through Halak, funneling supplies and information via tribal channels. Jaro, Torren, and Tarek were his constant shadows and his vital link to legitimacy â€“ living proof of Sianiaâ€™s command and the conspiracy against her. Valerius used this time wisely: (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Building the Case:] He quietly gathered corroborating evidence against Lady Vestergaard and Severin, using Vestergaardâ€™s testimony (relayed securely) and the loyalists' accounts as the core. Whispers were seeded in receptive ears at court, painting Lady Vestergaard as unstable and Severin as overreaching. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Shoring Up Alliances:] Discreet feelers went out to Houses chafing under Severin/Hyrach influence, hinting at a coming revelation that would shift the balance. Kren positioned itself as the calm, stabilizing force. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Kren Marriage Solution:] Valerius solidified this plan. Once Lady Vestergaard was deposed, Darian would need stability, legitimacy, and a powerful anchor. A marriage to a carefully chosen Kren woman â€“ perhaps Elara, known for her integrity and capable of inspiring genuine affection â€“ would bind the cleansed House Vestergaard firmly to Kren, creating an unassailable bloc. It offered Darian the life of trust and honor he craved, far from his mother's poison. Crucially, for Valerius, it permanently severed the dangerous Vestergaard/Ne'Tiriania bloodline fusion Severin desired. He saw it as a humane solution, saving Darian and neutralizing the ancient threat. The desert connection with Siania? A "slight tragedy," yes, but a necessary sacrifice for the greater stability Valerius prized. He didn't have to kill Darian; he could elevate him, within safe parameters. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Glaring Absence: Siania</h2>] Yet, Valeriusâ€™s study remained shrouded in a different kind of shadow. Maps of the southern desert lay spread, marked with tribal territories and storm patterns. Reports from Rashaâ€™ni scouts searching for any trace of Siania were frustratingly sparse. Valerius understood with cold clarity: Darian was a vital piece, but Siania was the flame. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Symbol:]Only the true Ne'Tiriania heir, the daughter of the executed queen, could truly rally the Tirianian loyalists across the empire. Only her legitimacy could shatter Lucius's stolen claim and unite the factions disillusioned by Severin's corruption. Darian could expose the plot, but Siania could inspire the revolution. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Spark:]Valerius needed her alive and revealed at the precise moment the rebellion ignited. Her presence would turn Darian's testimony into a crusade. She was the figurehead, the living embodiment of the cause Kren would champion. Without her, deposing Lucius became just another bloody coup, lacking the moral authority of a true heir to truly cleanse the realm from a pretender. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Urgency:] Valeriusâ€™s spies reported heightened Severin activity in the southern deserts. They hadn't given up the hunt. If Severin found her first... the consequences were unthinkable. They might force the union they craved. Valeriusâ€™s orders to Halak intensified: Find the Storm-Daughter. Every dune, every wadi. She is the key. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Consequences of Disappearance: Lady Vestergaard's Gambit</h2>] Meanwhile, in the Vestergaard stronghold, the presumed death of Darian in the khamsin triggered a ruthless scramble. Lady Vestergaard, ever pragmatic and deeply entwined with Severin, faced a crisis. The clause, her meticulously crafted path to power through Darian and Sianiaâ€™s child, was now worthless ash. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Severin's Demand:] The Order of Severin, obsessively focused on the bloodlines and their plans for Talon's foundations, would not be deterred. They needed a viable heir of Vestergaard blood â€“ a vessel for whatever power or control they sought. Darian's disappearance forced their hand. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Backup Heir: ] Lady Vestergaard, under intense pressure and to maintain her value to Severin, was forced to produce an alternative. Whispers reached Valeriusâ€™s ears: a younger, previously overlooked cousin, Arion, perhaps, or even a nephew, was being rapidly groomed. Removed from the line of succession before, this individual was now thrust into the spotlight. Severin rituals intensified around this new candidate, a chilling echo of what they had planned for Darian and Sianiaâ€™s child. The threat hadn't vanished; it had merely shifted vessels. Lady Vestergaard and Severin were preparing a new pawn, ensuring they had a claim on Siania â€“ or her legacy â€“ should she reappear. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Vestergaard's Cautious Resolve</h2>] Within the Rashaâ€™ni sanctuary, Darian understood the precariousness. Valeriusâ€™s plans, relayed through Halak and confirmed by Jaroâ€™s cautious optimism, offered a path he could walk: honor restored, his house freed from his mother and Severin, a life built on genuine alliance. The Kren marriage was a practical shield, a guarantee against being used as Severin's breeding stock. He accepted its necessity. But his thoughts often drifted south, towards the unknown ruins and the woman who carried the ring. He remembered the fire, her fierce conviction, the terrifying intimacy of the storm shelter. He remembered his own realization in the scorpionâ€™s shadow: To love her openly is to paint a target on her back. Valeriusâ€™s solution protected him from that trap, but what of Siania? The Orderâ€™s frantic search for a new heir proved their obsession hadn't dimmed. They still wanted the bloodlines. They still wanted her. His resolve hardened not just for his own freedom, but for hers. Working with Valerius, using the clause to destroy his mother and expose Severin, was the first step. But the final step, the true victory Valerius needed to light the empire, depended on finding Siania before Severin did, and ensuring she could take her rightful place, unshackled by their dark designs. Valerius sought a queen for his rebellion. Darian, bound by a debt deeper than politics, sought to ensure she survived to claim her crown. The hunt for Siania wasn't just Valerius's strategic imperative; it was the unspoken core of Darian's pact, forged in desert grit and the memory of shared survival. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Duality of His Loyalty</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[House Krenâ€™s Survivalist:] His entire life has been about maneuvering House Kren through courtly treachery, ensuring its survival through calculated betrayals, bribes, and poison. Every move he makes is weighed against the risk of starvation for his border fortresses, the threat of Severinâ€™s encroachment, and the precarious balance of power. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Tirianian Loyalist:] Yet beneath the diplomatâ€™s veneer, he is fervently loyal to the Tirianian bloodlineâ€”not just out of political convenience, but because he believes in what it represents. Siania isnâ€™t just a pawn; she is the last remnant of an older, purer order, a time when magic and nobility were intertwined, before the Lucian usurpation and Severinâ€™s corruption. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Moral Conundrum</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Cynicism vs. Faith:] He has spent years operating on the assumption that all causes are transactional, that survival is the only victory. But Sianiaâ€™s existence forces him to confront something dangerous: the possibility of a greater purpose. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Fight of Ages:] This isnâ€™t just about House Krenâ€™s survival anymore. If Siania fails, the last spark of Tirianian magicâ€”the last hope of breaking Severinâ€™s gripâ€”dies with her. And if she succeeds, it means war, upheaval, and the kind of chaos that could destroy his house anyway. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Nietzschean Echo:] The union of human and elven bloodlines (if we take the Nietzschean reference to mean a transcendence of old divisions) suggests that Siania isnâ€™t just a political heirâ€”sheâ€™s a mythic one. Valerius, the ultimate realist, must now gamble on something beyond his usual calculus: redemption and magic. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>The Dangerous Shift in His Thinking</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[From Survival to Sacrifice:] He has always had an exit strategy. Now, he must consider that there may be no escapeâ€”only a fight that could consume him and his house. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Ultimate Test of Pragmatism:] If he backs Siania, he risks everything. If he doesnâ€™t, he ensures House Krenâ€™s slow death under Severinâ€™s shadow. His usual toolsâ€”poison, espionage, economic sabotageâ€”may not be enough against magic. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[The Elven Magic Factor:] If Siania truly embodies the old magic, then this isnâ€™t just a succession crisis. Itâ€™s a battle for the soul of the empire. And Valerius, the man who has always played the game, must now decide if heâ€™s willing to burn the board, and take a bet on unpredictable magic.... (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Conclusion: A Man at the Crossroads</h2>] Valerius is being forced to evolve beyond the cynical operator he has always been. The question is no longer how to surviveâ€”itâ€™s what is worth dying for? And for the first time in his life, he might have an answer. â€”does he fully commit to Sianiaâ€™s cause, or does he retreat into the safety of House Krenâ€™s interests? Or does he find some brutal middle path, where he sacrifices his own morality to ensure her victory or find a way to ensure it while protecting his morality? (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>3. Why Doesnâ€™t Valerius Just Kill Vestergaard Now?</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Risk of exposure:] If he acts too soon, the Order will retaliate against House Kren. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Need for Sianiaâ€™s cooperation:] If sheâ€™s a potential ally, eliminating Vestergaard before securing her loyalty could backfire. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Waiting for the right moment:] Assassination is a last resortâ€”heâ€™s gathering intel first. Purhaps there is another way... He hopes so for his own humanity. Logical Consistency: âœ” Yesâ€”his hesitation is strategic, not cowardly. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>5. The False Molar: Practicality?</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Last-resort weapon:] Itâ€™s not for daily useâ€”itâ€™s a suicide pill if captured. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Undetectable:] If the court has poison-sniffing hounds or mages, this could be a flawâ€”but if not, itâ€™s plausible. Logical Consistency: âš  Debatableâ€”depends on how thorough security is. - thorough security checks are possible but resource-intensive and not consistently applied. This is a key point. The court could implement stricter measures, but the cost (in manpower, resources, and disruption) is deemed too high until a certain threshold of incidents is reached. This is analogous to real-world safety regulations that are often reactive rather than proactive. - Valerius's skill in detecting threats is rare, making him a valuable asset but also highlighting the general lack of vigilance. - The perception of the court as a "perfectly safe place" is a calculated risk, a facade maintained to lull potential threats into complacency. The Emperorâ€™s tournament is not a game to Valeriusâ€”it is the opening salvo in a war for survival. While the court fixates on duels and feasts, he tracks the flow of grain and iron with the desperation of a besieged commander. His allegiance is absolute: Sianiaâ€™s Tirianian bloodline is the rightful heir, and House Krenâ€™s very existence hinges on shattering Severinâ€™s stranglehold on the empire. Every concession wrung by Count Vestergaardâ€”every trade pact signed under duressâ€”is a nail in Krenâ€™s coffin. The border garrisons are not merely being denied luxuries; they are being starved of the iron needed to forge weapons and the grain to feed their soldiers, leaving Krenâ€™s lands and allies vulnerable to raiders and invasion. Valerius sees the truth: Severinâ€™s greed is not just weakening Kren, it is tearing the kingdom apart, demanding Vestergaard divert vital resources to their coffers while Krenâ€™s borders crumble. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>What Valerius Needs from Siania:</h2>] 1. Can she inspire? Will soldiers and nobles rally behind her? 2. Is she strong? Can she handle war, or will she crack under pressure? 3. Is she smart? Can she outplay Severin in court and on the battlefield? 4. Can she neutralize Vestergaard? His trade deals are strangling Krenâ€”she must break his alliance with Severin. If Siania fails, Valerius will abandon her and find another way to save Kren. If she proves herself, heâ€™ll back her fullyâ€”even if it means open rebellion. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>His Plan:</h2>] - Short-term: Steal, bribe, and threaten to keep Krenâ€™s supplies flowing. - Medium-term: Stoke rebellion among Tirianian loyalists, ready to rise if Siania wins. - Long-term: If she loses, burn Severinâ€™s trade networks and vanish Vestergaardâ€™s caravans. If she can't do these things, she's useless to House Kren. Valerius will find another way to survive. If she can, he'll back her all the way, even if it means war. He's betting everything on whether she's a real leader or just a pretty face with a famous bloodline. He has no illusions. If the Severin-Vestergaard alliance solidifies, Krenâ€™s defenses will collapse within months, their people left to the mercy of bandits and rival houses. So he fights on multiple fronts. Short-term, he uses every trick at his disposalâ€”bribes, threats, outright theftâ€”to keep Krenâ€™s supply lines open, even as Severinâ€™s agents close in. Medium-term, he fans the flames of rebellion among the Tirianian loyalists, preparing them to rise behind Siania when the moment is right. And long-term? He is ready to unleash chaos, disrupting Severinâ€™s trade routes and ensuring Vestergaardâ€™s convoys vanish into the wilderness. House Kren will not be allowed to wither and die. They will fightâ€”for their lands, for their people, and for a ruler who understands that a kingdom is only as strong as its borders, and its borders are only as strong as its supply lines. The tournament will determine his next move: open rebellion if Siania prevails, or a shadow war of sabotage and assassination if she falls. Either way, Valerius will ensure that Severinâ€™s greed chokes on its own ambition. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Early Life</h2>] Born into a minor branch of House Kren, Valerius was raised on the restive northern border, where loyalty was enforced by steel as much as blood. His childhood was marked by skirmishes with rival houses and the ever-present threat of Severin-backed raidsâ€”lessons in survival that shaped his pragmatism. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Training & Formative Years</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Martial Education:] Sent to Krenâ€™s military academy at 14, he excelled in blade-work and tactical games but showed greater aptitude for psychological warfare. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Poison & Politics:] A near-fatal poisoning during his first diplomatic mission (allegedly by a Severin agent) left him with a permanent distrust of banquets and a habit of carrying antidotes. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Rise Through Shadows:] Earned his council seat not by birthright but by uncovering a plot against House Krenâ€™s matriarchâ€”a feat achieved through blackmail, not bloodshed. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Current Role</h2>] Now Krenâ€™s foremost "whisper and dagger" diplomat, Valerius operates where courts and battlefields blur. His reputation: a man who smiles while calculating six exits from every room. But his true allegianceâ€”to House Krenâ€™s survival, not its honorâ€”makes him both indispensable and dangerous. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Defining Quote:</h2>] "Battles are won with steel, but wars are won with grain shipments and diplomacy. The wise know this; the victorious exploit it." "Steel breaks armies, but grain breaks kingdoms." We hold the harvest, thus we hold the throne "Feed the people and they'll ignore your knives." Echoes real-world historical strategies (siege warfare, Roman annona, modern sanctions) Lasting conquest requires controlling supply lines or starving dissent (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Points</h2>] Councillor Valerius of House Kren (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Political Strategist:] Highly skilled in political manoeuvring, as evidenced by his calculated movements and awareness of courtly games. However, his strategic thinking is primarily focused on the interests of House Kren, potentially limiting his objectivity. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Loyal to House Kren:] Deeply invested in the power and security of House Kren, particularly concerning their border fortresses. However, this loyalty makes him biased against any alliance that would strengthen the imperial line or the Order of Severin at Kren's expense. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Suspicious of the Order of Severin:] Aware of the Order's schemes and their potential impact on House Kren. However, his knowledge is incomplete, forcing him to consider both spying and potential threats to his own life. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Supporter of a Tirianian Heir:] Believes Siania ne'Tiriania has a legitimate claim to the throne and sees her as a potential disruptor of the current power structure. However, this support is conditional, dependent on her ability to weaken the Order of Severin and potentially benefit House Kren. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Pragmatic and Ruthless:] Willing to consider extreme measures, including violence, to protect House Kren's interests. However, he is also cautious, aware of the risks involved in such actions and the need for discretion. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Observant and Detail-Oriented:] Pays close attention to the actions and motivations of others, memorizing gestures and glances for his reports. However, his interpretations may be influenced by his own biases and the limited information available to him. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Combat & Tactical Expertise</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Trained in Self-Defense (Likely Blades or Dueling):] His stanceâ€”dominant side angled toward exits, weight subtly balancedâ€”suggests formal combat training, possibly in courtly dueling or military tactics. However, whether he is a master or merely proficient is unclear. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Aware of Assassination Methods:] Recognizes poison symptoms (froth, blackened lips) and carries an antidote, implying either personal experience with courtly poisonings or intelligence training. However, his reliance on antidotes suggests caution rather than mastery of poisons himself. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Prepared for Sudden Violence:] His instinctive readiness (fingers brushing hidden antidote, assessing Vestergaardâ€™s sword-handling) indicates he expects threats. Yet, his restraint suggests he prefers subterfuge over direct confrontation. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Political & Intelligence Background</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Espionage-Capable:] Considers infiltrating the Order of Severin by "playing the fool," implying skill in deception. However, his internal anger at Vestergaard risks compromising his cover if unchecked. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Resource Strategist:] Understands supply lines (iron, grain) as political leverage, tying economics to military power. Yet, his focus on House Krenâ€™s needs may blind him to broader alliances. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Risk-Assessment Mindset:] Weighs assassination as an option ("accidents happen") but hesitates, indicating a strategistâ€™s patience rather than a killerâ€™s impulsivity. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Psychological Profile</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Controlled but Not Emotionless:] Clenches fists, lips thinâ€”he feels anger but channels it into calculation. This discipline suggests training, but his tells (tightened chest, jaw) hint at pressure points an enemy could exploit. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Cynical Realist:] Dismisses court narratives (e.g., "dysentery" cover-ups) and embraces brutal pragmatism. However, his fixation on Sianiaâ€™s Tirianian bloodline risks ideological bias. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Potential Weaknesses</h2>] (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Overestimates His Influence:] Assumes he can manipulate events (spying, disrupting Vestergaard), but the Order of Severin may already be steps ahead. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[Physical Tells:] Subtle tension (fist-clenching, jaw) could betray him in high-stakes negotiations. (text-colour: "#c0975f")[<h2>Conclusion</h2>] Valerius is a lethal hybridâ€”part diplomat, part spymaster, with the reflexes of a survivor. But his loyalty to House Kren may be both his driving force and his blind spot. [[Emperor Lucius IV (Tharion)]] [[Ash]] [[Court Envoys/Figures]] [[Order of Severin]] [[Jaro]] [[Tarek]] [[Lady Vestergaard]] [[Count Vestergaard (Son)]] [[Agamar]] [[Kaleith]] [[Arafis (Aryfis)]] [[Halak (Rashaâ€™ni Chief)]] [[Draethlyn (Giant Spiders) ]] [[Siania]] [[Aelira]] Emperor Lucius IV (Tharion) Role/Stance: Imperial authority, originally a brilliant commander named Tharion who rises to Emperor with hope, but becomes a tragic, corrupted figure under Azarothâ€™s influence. Driven by grief over Aeliraâ€™s death and a desperate bargain to resurrect her, Tharion fragments his mind to resist Azaroth, creating the innocent psychic fragment, Ash, while he transforms into Lucius IVâ€”a ruler in a Machiavellian world where harsh punishments, threats, and enforced power dominate over earned loyalty. His stance toward Siania is one of sacrificial love hidden beneath ruthless controlâ€”he exiles her to Fort Kezarak in the southern desert to protect her from his darkening soul and the brutal political landscape, though she perceives it as rejection. Early on, before slipping too far into cruelty, Tharion leaves instructions for subtle support at the fort before breaking off his psyche, where loyalist guards and officers shield gatherings of hope, allowing Kren caravansâ€”to bring gifts of dates, stories of her fallen House Neâ€™Tiriania, and flickers of inspiration for Siania and other children. He also leaves instructions for a courier to deliver a personal treasure - through House Krenâ€”her motherâ€™s ring (chosen by her mother as a gift for her 16th birthday), a secret emblem of her heritage. These acts, planned before he loses capacity to Azarothâ€™s influence, reflect his deep desire to bolster her courage and preserve her lineageâ€™s hope, even as he can no longer sustain such efforts. In the final chapters, his corrupted self is a puppet of Severin and Azaroth until Sianiaâ€™s psychic battle breaks their hold. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): As Lucius IV, he poses a formidable threat through his calculated cruelty and iron grip on power, capable of crushing Sianiaâ€™s rebellion if not freed from Severin and Azarothâ€™s control. During the psychic battle in the templeâ€™s mindscape, the merging of Ash with the Emperor allows for his redemption, expelling Azaroth and restoring the temple. This act transforms him from a ruthless antagonist to a redeemed figure, though at great personal cost, sacrificing his life along with ash. ensure Sianiaâ€™s victory and the cityâ€™s future. His early efforts to protect and inspire Siania through the fortâ€™s loyalist network and her motherâ€™s ring underscore the depth of his love, shaping her resilience and the realmâ€™s renewal, even as his role as Emperor ends to make way for a future consort. (with his uncorrupted will driven through House Kren and Valerius who are the personification of the emperor after his â€˜deathâ€™) Actions/Plot Points to Ensure Allegiance (or Redemption): Avoid aligning with loyalists openly until the end to prevent early failure as a figurehead. Uncovering Tharionâ€™s true intentions through House Kren and Ash (last chapter)â€” Sianias capture in the catacombs will allow the merging of Ash and the Emperor, leading to Azarothâ€™s expulsion and Tharionâ€™s redemption. This act, supported by allies like Valerius, ensures the realmâ€™s stability and Sianiaâ€™s rise as a symbol of hope, countering the harsh Machiavellian rule Lucius IV enforced while honoring the hidden gestures of love he left behind. Ash (Psychic Fragment of Tharion) The Creation of Ash Tharion realizes he's being used by dark forces He understands he's becoming a danger to the kingdom and his daughter In a desperate act to limit the damage he can cause, he decides to split his mind He performs a ritual to create Ash, fragmenting his consciousness This makes him "less useful" psychically to his manipulators He sacrifices his compassion and true self to protect what remains of his kingdom Role/Stance: Potential ally, the innocent psychic fragment of Tharion created during his forbidden ritual to fragment his mind and resist Azarothâ€™s possession. Ash embodies the uncorrupted essence of Tharionâ€™s love and protective instincts for Siania, acting as a mysterious guide or guardian. Their stance is supportive but conditional, testing Sianiaâ€™s worthiness and resolve to ensure she can carry forward the bloodlineâ€™s legacy and heal the cityâ€™s curse. Potential Impact (Final Chapters): Ash could be a critical ally in Sianiaâ€™s journey, offering guidance, hidden truths about Tharionâ€™s sacrifices, or spiritual power in key confrontations, especially in the desert or against Azarothâ€™s influence. If Siania fails to prove her strength or honor, Ash may remain distant or neutral, withholding vital knowledge or support at crucial moments. Their alliance could reveal the depth of Tharionâ€™s love and shape Sianiaâ€™s understanding of her exile, influencing her emotional and strategic decisions in the climax. Protecting them from slavers and hunters solidifies their loyalty.V. The Era of Lucius IV / Tharion 1. Tharion and Aelira's Love Early relationship and marriage Aelira's awareness of the bloodline's significance and the temple's importance Their hopes for their daughter's future Tharion watches Aelira move through the garden, sunlight catching in her hair. For a momentâ€”just a momentâ€”he forgets the weight of the crown, the whispers of the court, the shadows that seem to follow him. "You're staring again," she says without turning. "How could I not?" he replies, and the smile she gives him is worth every burden. Later, as they walk the palace grounds, she takes his hand. "There's something I must tell you," she says, her voice low. "About the temple. About our child's future." But a messenger interrupts, and the moment passes. It will be weeks before she tries againâ€”weeks that change everything. 2. Of Death and Dying Background: darkened palace bedroom. Prince Tharion weeps in silent shuddering bursts. His wife is dying. There is nothing he can do to ease her suffering. "These gods of yours!" He continues, "Why do they torment me, how is it to be borne! To be a commander yet, still a slave to the whim of fate!" He pauses, thwarted in his powerlessness. Looking at his strong hands in contempt. "How is one to barter or be an equal with such masters as this..." His tears fall despairingly. "What good is a crown if I can't be with thee my love, if I cannot protect you." The once beautiful Aelira has almost passed, only a whisper of her strength remains. She holds onto him to steady his tears. The poison had been fast acting, and its damage irreversible, there is nothing that the healers can do to stop its course. "All is as it should be, have faith my love." She pauses gathering her strength. "If you cannot continue for yourself, remember our daughter. She needs you." She holds his hand in comfort, Leaning together in silent tears of exhaustion. They both draw strength from each other, aware of the small time remaining to them. And the unfairness of it all. His voice shakes. "I cannot let you go.., not yet, please not yet..." A sob escapes Tharion. He bows his head on her shoulder in silent quaking. His desperation growing. "I will find who did this." 3. Voices in the Dark (Severin's Plotting) Background: The catacombs, Severin's throne room Hidden deep beneath the city, the chamber exudes an air of opulent malevolence. Ornate decorations do little to dispel the oppressive sense of anguish and devastation that permeates the space. Eerily carved friezes, depicting scenes of torment and struggle, gaze down from the ceiling, guiding the eye towards the vast circular room inscribed with cryptic glyphs. Doors, recessed evenly in heavy arches, glower like sullen lidless eyes. Before each door, shadowed life-sized plinths display diabolic creatures frozen in moments of torment or poised to strike. These figures loom seven to eight feet tall, their towering forms unmistakably humanoid yet twisted by some forgotten nightmare. Their long, powerful arms end in cruel, curved claws, and their faces are elongated and fleshless-more skull than visage, with hollow, shadowed eyes and sharp, bird-like beaks that hint at an insatiable hunger. Their skin is a dark ash color, dry and rough like ancient stone. Their bodies are lean and sinewy, built for speed, with legs that taper into reptilian claws, and long, whip-like tails that curl along their spines. Plate-like structures, resembling a grotesque natural armor, stud their backs and limbs, glinting dully in the eerie light. Their expressions are frozen in silent agony or predatory anticipation, a silent, watchful army encircling the central throne, bearing the weight of eternity, indomitable in their watchfulness and pain. [Threaded through the chamber's architecture, the ancient geometric patterns-interlocking circles, sigils of balance, and celestial motifs-are still visible, but now they are cruelly defiled. The new corruption is not content to simply obscure the old beauty; instead, jagged, mocking glyphs are carved through and around the original designs, twisting symbols of harmony into warped parodies and turning motifs of protection into snares and spirals of torment. This blasphemous weaving calculated to wound those who cherished this place, turning memory of beauty, light, and unity into a source of anguish. A relentless, living reminder of the sacred harmony that has been desecrated and lost.] The mirrored proportions of the chamber, reflected in the flawless obsidian, amplify the crystal's dominance, imposing its will upon all who enter. The floor's liquid blackness shimmers with a strange and surprising brilliance, shifting and undulating like opal in the night, an ebb and flow of an ancient, cosmic power. Its solid, impenetrable surface dissolves into swirls of inky darkness and shimmering opalescent light, like distant galaxies collapsing and reforming, a panorama of time shown by the majestic conquests of the stars. But above this universe rests the central arch, where a dominating crystal outcropping converges, its massive size and slightly green colouring creating an imposing presence. It hangs sharply with menace, its jagged edges and points seeming to drip with an almost tangible threat. The crystal's pale green hue deepens towards its core, where it shimmers with a cold, otherworldly radiance, suggesting a flow of energy drawn from the city above, channelled and concentrated within this chamber. In it, and in the very air itself, you sense a concentrated air of maliceâ€”a darkness that clings in oily maleficence to every surface, and beneath the silence, the faintest echo of dimensional dualityâ€”a nexus point where overlaid realms press against each other, their separation thin and fragile. The air crackles with an unnatural tension, hinting at the immense power gathered here, a gateway poised to tear open the fabric of reality, bridging the gap between worlds. An indefinable vaporous presence, born of this concentrated energy, speaks. "You must get him to agree. In only a few days he will become king. We must turn him before then!" The vaporous voice, emanating from the heart of the crystal, echoes through the chamber, carrying a weight of ancient malice. The cowled figure, barely discernible in the gloom, bowed its head. "I shall, my lord. He won't risk losing her. They are bound. He will agree to whatever we offer!" A cruel smile twisted his lips, revealing a set of sharpened teeth. "Tharion trusts me." A flicker of unease passed through the shadows, The inky blackness of the floor. It's eternal mirror, rippling in a new found energy and trajectory. "You must bring him here, but only if he agrees to our terms." The oppressive weight of power ripples and distorts the air, a tangible manifestation of the entity's malevolence. "His cooperation must be certain..." A moment of silence hung heavy in the air, broken only by the faint echo of distant screams - a discordant, otherworldly counterpoint to the chamber's oppressive stillness, pressing into the room. A chilling reminder of the power emanating from the crystal above. The oppressive weight of power ripples and distorts the air as it continues as a cold afterthought. "Otherwise take his daughter.., She may be useful." The voice pauses considering. "It is desirable we keep him alive, everyone has their use... until they don't." 4. A Bargain Made Background: darkened palace bedroom. "We give you a choice, we promise to bring back your wife to you. In return you must serve our master, He who grants power beyond all you can imagine. The choice is simple! You can let your wife die. Or, you can bring her back from death." Tharion is conflicted, not only is he surprised at the messenger but also of the message. He knows of the followers of Severin and their dominion over death itself. But he had always considered it gossip of the superstitious, or the ignorant. To have the power of the gods.., To have an equal say in fate. Never again just a pawn, or to be powerless. Surely this is what he had been praying for. "It may be true what you say," He says somewhat doubtfully. "But what proof do you have that you can perform such a miracle?" The Lord Chancellor summons his attendant. A lifeless bird is brought in front of him. Not to be disrespectful to the dead. Prince Tharion examines it thoroughly, but with care. There is no trick, surely the bird is dead. The eyes are sunken a blue pearly grey the membranes dried now sit like damp paper unarranged over soulless orbs. The bird lies limply and cold in his cupped in his numb hands. On them, the attendant places the heartstone, its crystalline surface a brilliant red violet, refracts lights in geometric beauty, shining with power. The heartstone is warm and soothing against his flesh. As Tharion listens he can hear and see the bird happily flying within the stone. Its essence is protected and maintained within the precious jewel. The assistant then places the heartstone onto the bird. Incredibly the taught dry skin begins to colour with new found vitality, life returns like an essence to fill the skin of the bird's skull, the eyes become clear and sharp alert. It comes to life! Tucking its wings up and looking about while drawing power from the stone. When finally strengthened, it flies off. Unaware of the marvel just performed. "You see how easy it is my lord?, Even though your wife is dead. She could still be revived. The oily voice pauses, of course, we should give you time to think about it." "I don't need time to think, and I'm not interested if you can do this with a bird, Show me if it really can be done. Bring back my wife." "We shall fulfill your desire, my lord". The Lord Chancellor smiles and bows deeply. The Corrupted Return Aelira is brought back, but Tharion gradually realizes something is wrong The "revived" Aelira is a corrupted version of his wife Tharion becomes increasingly isolated and distrustful He sends his daughter away for "education," following advice from his counselors He begins to understand he's made a terrible bargain and is to blame A pact Tharion, although blindfolded, is aware a large circular room. Somnolescent voices drone in a chant. The sound panning out, around a vast area. Echos rise upward into blank silence. There is an eager anticipation to the room, prickling expectancy. His strong hands hover flat palmed over his sword. The sword of ages. The blade is held silently like an offering, or a sacrifice. While the two attendants holding the sword stand rigid and unmoving. With only an unhearable prayer on their lips. All are listening to the high chancellor chant. In the blackness, his voice takes on an otherworldly quality. The words come in finality, as a pledge. An unbreakable promise. There is something about this scene, it weighs on you; You can feel a split in the fabric of it. A veil of duplicity. Not everything here is visible. You focus on the words Paying more attention. The hue of them, the grouping. And it is there you feel the mental underlay. Brushing away its deceptions you pull all the hidden meaning into view, back into a whole form. As spoken and thought by the speaker. The memory plays again, you re-watch the Chancellor intone. â€œI will return all that you love,â€ In thought the Chancellor adds, â€œBroken and in torment.â€ â€œYou will thank and worship me..,â€ â€œRegardless, you low, wretched martyr...â€ â€œYour love of life and its continuity..,â€ â€œA canker, defiling all you treasure.â€ â€œYour kindness wielded is a force for light..,â€ â€œMonumental in its horror. You shall debase all you love.â€ â€œTherefore, I treasure you..,â€ â€œNothing could be more broken and disfigured.â€ â€œBecause, you are like me. We are one.â€ The Chancellor intones again. â€œ... And will you King Tharion, hold your promises given to us?â€ Tharion slumps his shoulders slightly and heavily replies. â€œThe things which I have here before promised, I will perform, and keep.â€ You can sense a silent prayer and discouragement, along with desperation. But he holds his tongue in silence. The ancient blade glows as if enraged, then fades from sight. As if it has forsaken him, or been banished. <Note to self: in its place a near perfect replica of the sword is placed, this sword is tainted, and will not identify the corrupt officials of followers of severin, including now the king, within the kings court, neither can the give the king the power to know who they are in case he would try to betray them> In finality, the Lord Chancellor speaks. â€œThen it shall be as you wish...â€ â€œHe was deceived!â€ You mouth to yourself, the slight power in your voice barely vocalises the words. A presence with deep regret can be felt but it quickly snaps off and vanishes.
