Never make deals with the devil, As it was he that invented contracts!â€ You perceive a misty form capering around you mockingly. Leaning in sharply, it whispers musicallyâ€¦, â€œWhat he didnâ€™t know, was just how much the chancellor hated him!â€¦ Memories.., Ahhh!. So en-ter-tain-ing!â€ With several mocking flourishes, He skips off back, fading into the blackness! Coronation of the Sun â€œOnce again from above, with waves I do forment, I incite the waters and lead them ashore the gray torrent. Frothing in torment fights with the wall. Where the shadow stands watchful The ridge over the deep; Then obscured behind it blended with the sea comes another surge.â€ The day of the coronation brings excited and grateful crowds. Prince Tharion is admired across the land, as noble and brave. His wife the elegant Lady Aelira stands together with him lovingly, Holding their baby, the princess Siania. The final lines of the ceremony flow into the crowd, marking a new age. â€œâ€¦ And so receive this kingly sword, The sword of ages, in innocence and judgment, as a proof of the godsâ€™ protection; and also as an emblem of a promise that binds you with your nation, its lands and people. Be strong and of good courage, that you may be a king of our age in justice and glory!â€ The blade signifies acceptance of him, as of pure heart and true. It is a blade that can never lie.<Note to self: highlight it as a fake sword in Aeliras dreams, They iterate with new details each time, to finally reveal the truth> Finally to the crowd the Lord Chancellor turns. â€œAnd you dear people, we ask for your recognition. All who come this day to do homage and service. Are you willing to do the same, and have this man as your king?â€ Tharion has for years been a respected leader, holding the region strong through battles or famine. All feel proud and confident to have such a king. In these thoughts, The People proclaim their enthusiasm with joy, by loud and repeated acclamations. All with one voice crying out. Solemnly the crown is placed on Tharion. He steps forward gravely and bows weighted and thoughtful, almost as if in penitence. His blade flashing magnificently, its elven crated metal swirls with power as he holds it high in the spring sun. In resolution of the ceremony, trumpets ring true and clear, accompanied by a flock of white birds soaring up into the sky. With light hearts red rose petals fall in scented showers touching servants and nobles alike, bonding them in joy. â€œRed.., the colour of sacrifice..,â€ the voice mocks in ironic mirth. Rebirth of the moon <Notes to self Rebirth of the moon: The queen has a night mare, and realises she had died But doesnt yet realisewhat has happend, Tharion deal etc, but instead worries she may be losing her mind> It is the day of the coronation. The Lord Chancellorâ€™s words ring above all. â€œBe strong and of good courage, that you may be a king of our age in justice and glory!â€ Theodoricâ€™s words ring in acceptance of this command with vibrancy, The words echo and fade, distorted against the columns of the mighty cathedral. Looking at the crowd, Aelira is buoyed by the joyful faces she sees, looking at him in tenderness. Luminous and effervescent crowds. The velvety rose petals fall, their fragrance sweet and enduring. A small peasant boy runs smiling at her. In his hands a hidden gift which he imparts to her wordlessly, with solemn innocence. She opens her cupped hands to reveal a small dead bird. In shock she looks up, back to the boy. He studies her face with sadness. His eyes dark and wise, aged with care.., seemingly at congruities with such a young body. He seems to fade back into himself somehow. Leaving the young boy to run off. In revulsion she stares at the dead bird, her hands feel immobile, unable to release the corpse to the ground. The flesh is Rotten and pustulant, pocked with small maggots moving within the thin shell of semitransparent skin. They feast uninterrupted, indifferent to her horror. However, It is the coldness of the body that shocks her, the emptiness so consuming... Almost as if she is being sucked into the blackness. It draws her in... Queen Aelira wakes sharply. â€œI died.., I am sure it is so.â€ She scans back to her last memories, although clouded... She felt the hopelessness of her sickness and final acceptance of death. In the last days she had welcomed it. A strange blankness and sudden fragility stops her from probing her thoughts further. She mouths to herself. â€œBut it cannot be.â€ Aelira tries to calm her thoughts. Reaching for the princess, she holds her gently, tucking in the soft woollen blanket. Attempting to rock them both to sleep. Failing, she continues to stare into the night silently, swaying back and forth. The Night Before Battle Background: A military tent on the outskirts of the Eastlands. The night before battle. The map before Tharion shows the terrain where tomorrow's blood will flow. His generals have departed, leaving him alone with his thoughts and the flickering lamplight. Outside, the camp settles into an uneasy quietâ€”thousands of men trying to find sleep before dawn brings death. He doesn't believe in this war. The "Eastland Rebellion" feels manufactured, a convenient enemy conjured by his counselors. Three months ago, these people were loyal subjects. Now, they are traitors who must be put to the sword. "For the security of the realm," Lord Chancellor Severin had insisted. "These dissidents threaten everything we've built." But what have we built? Tharion wonders, staring at the map without seeing it. The city he left behind is no longer the place he once loved. The streets have grown dangerous, neighbors suspicious of neighbors. People disappearâ€”critics of the new policies, scholars who question the historical records, priests who speak of the old ways. And Aelira... something is wrong with Aelira. She moves differently, speaks differently. Sometimes he catches her staring at their daughter with an expression he cannot name but that chills his blood. When he confronts her, she smiles in a way that doesn't reach her eyes and speaks of being "merely tired." He takes out parchment and quill. Perhaps writing to her will help him find the woman he once knew in the stranger who now wears her face. Excerpt from the Personal Diary of Lucius IV "In some cases, I gladden the minds of many. From a distance, I comfort those I turn war against. The harm and healing, they sense it. Now and again, over deep woe, I better their fortunes." From the Unsent Papers of Lucius IV (Written before the Battle of Eastlands) There are those whose gifts are not gifts at all, but preludes to suffering, their favours bestowed with a smile as cold as the blade that follows. I have seen such workings-how a shadow moves among men, weaving hope and despair with equal skill. â€¦A shadow, a presence that gladdens the mind with promises, only to draw out the marrow of a soul in the next breath. From afar, he soothes the very hearts he intends to break, his comfort a poison, his distance an illusion. It is his way to turn kin against kin, to set war in motion with a whisper, then offer solace to the wounded-never for healing's sake, but to deepen the wound, to ensure the cycle continues. Those who have felt his hand know both the sting and the balm, for he is the master of both harm and healing. His power is a tide, receding only to return stronger, dragging all beneath its undertow. Suffering becomes his harvest, and in the aftermath of every calamity, he is there-offering fortune, but only after the soul has been hollowed by woe. So it is, and so it has always been: his gifts are the prelude to ruin, his comfort the herald of conflict. In the end, all that is left is the echo of his laughter, and the knowledge that every fortune he bestows is but the beginning of another fall. Forgive me, for it was with such a one that I made a bargainâ€¦ These were not choices freely made, but necessities pressed upon me by fate and duty-each step taken because there was no other path, or none I could see. In the end, I did only what was demanded. And for that my dearest, I lost you. Sometimes I wish I could go back-just once-to those childhood days before these bitter fruitsâ€¦, when I was only Ash, and you were still by my side, before the world grew so heavy. I will look for you always, although I know I shall never see you again in this life. Please, forgive me. ~ Ash He stares at the words he has written, particularly the childhood name he hasn't used in decades. Ash. The name his mother called him, before titles and duties weighed him down. Before the bargain that changed everything. The letter will never be sent. He knows this even as he folds it carefully and seals it with wax. Tomorrow, he will lead men to die for a cause he no longer believes in. And when he returns homeâ€”if he returnsâ€”Aelira's will be waiting. But he finds instead of his heart being at ease at the thought that it is unsettledâ€¦ Something must be done. Something to protect what remains of his kingdom, and his daughter. < Uh, this is the part we don't tell the reader because it's the big reveal at the end. The ash is the emperor. The thought comes to him then, remembered from ancient texts in the forbidden section of the royal library: a ritual of division, of protection through fragmentation. A desperate measure for desperate times. As the camp falls silent and the night deepens, Tharion begins to plan.> The Creation of Ash Tharion realizes he's being used by dark forces He understands he's becoming a danger to the kingdom and his daughter In a desperate act to limit the damage he can cause, he decides to split his mind He performs a ritual to create Ash, fragmenting his consciousness This makes him "less useful" psychically to his manipulators He sacrifices his compassion and true self to protect what remains of his kingdom The Arranged Marriage The counselors, now controlling the corrupted Tharion, arrange for his daughter to marry a cruel partner They target her because of her mother's bloodline, which is the one connected to the temple The corrupted Tharion, now completely evil, approves of this arrangement This planned marriage becomes the catalyst for the protagonist's escape and the beginning of the main story Excerpt from the Personal Diary of Lucius IV â€œIn some cases, I gladden the minds of many. From a distance, I comfort those I turn war against. The harm and healing, they sense it. Now and again, over deep woe, I better their fortunes.â€ From the Unsent Papers of Lucius IV (Written before departing the city) There are those whose gifts are not gifts at all, but preludes to suffering, their favours bestowed with a smile as cold as the blade that follows. It is his way to turn kin against kin, to set war in motion with a whisper, then offer solace to the wounded-never for healingâ€™s sake, but to deepen the wound, to ensure the cycle continues. Those who have felt his hand know both the sting and the balm, for he is the master of both harm and healing. His power is a tide, receding only to return stronger, dragging all beneath its undertow. Suffering becomes his harvest, and in the aftermath of every calamity, he is there-offering fortune, but only after the soul has been hollowed by woe. So it is, and so it has always been: his gifts are the prelude to ruin, his comfort the herald of conflict. In the end, all that is left is the echo of his laughter, and the knowledge that every fortune he bestows is but the beginning of another fall. I will look for you always, although I know I shall never see you again in this life. Please, forgive me. ~ Ash Scene Summary: At the storyâ€™s end, after the Emperorâ€™s death and Azarothâ€™s defeat, this wish is finally granted-not through power, but through release and forgiveness. As the psychic realm dissolves, you witness a vision in a sun-dappled forest clearing. The little boy-Ash-stands uncertain at the edge of the light. Slowly, he transforms into a young, innocent version of the Emperor, unburdened by years of darkness. There, waiting in the golden, silvery sunlight, is a young woman: his wife, your mother, also freed at last. For a moment, they hesitate-tentative, almost not daring to believe. Then recognition dawns, and their faces brighten with wonder and relief. The young Emperor reaches out; she takes his hand. Before they step into the radiant light, both turn and look at you. The young womanâ€™s features are strikingly similar to your own. She smiles-a smile filled with both happiness and sorrow, joyful to be free and reunited, yet sad because she cannot stay with you. Their eyes linger on you, conveying love, pride, and a silent farewell. Together, they step into the sunlight, laughter and joy echoing as the forest closes protectively around them-accepting, sheltering, and finally, at peace. In this moment, Lucius/Ashâ€™s deepest wish is answered: He returns to the days before everything became so heavy, finds her again, and is welcomed home by the gentle light and the embrace of the forest. The cycle of suffering is broken, and what was lost is, at last, restored-not in the world he ruled, but in the peace he could never find until now. The heartstone The Pact: Azarothâ€™s Vision of Betrayal You stumble through the labyrinth, the world lurching beneath your feet. The air thickens, heavy with the scent of incense and old stone. Azarothâ€™s presence coils around your mind, cold and suffocating. Suddenly, you are not yourself. The faces of the fallenâ€”men, women, childrenâ€”flash before you, their eyes full of accusation. Tharion stands at the center, the false sword in his grip, his face a mask of guilt and resolve. The visionâ€™s aftertaste clings, bitter and unresolved. <h2>Scene: Port of Talon â€“ Aryfisâ€™s View</h2> Aryfis the marketplace imp flowers sulkily and stomps his tiny clawed foot on the salt-stained planks of the Talon docks. The cityâ€™s air is thick with brine, fish guts, and the shouts of sailors, but Aryfis is in no mood for the bustle. His tail flicks in irritation, nearly tripping a passing dockhand, who yelps and scurries away, muttering about â€œdevil-kin and their curses.â€ He should be proud. He, Aryfis, has crossed deserts, braved haunted citadels, and survived Sianiaâ€™s cooking. Yet here he is, ignored, his grand plans for mischief stifled by the seriousness of their mission. Siania is all business, the pirate is sharpening his cutlass, and nobody has even noticed the clever way Aryfis â€œborrowedâ€ a pouch of silver from a distracted merchant. (Heâ€™ll return it. Maybe. If he remembers.) He scampers between crates, eyeing the bustling port for opportunity. A glint of something shinyâ€”buttons, coins, a polished boot buckleâ€”always draws his gaze. But today, even the prospect of petty theft feels hollow. Siania is tense, her eyes fixed on the distant palace spires. Aryfis senses the weight of her purpose, and it makes his own claws itch. Still, an impâ€™s got to do what an impâ€™s got to do. He slips away from the group, ducking behind a stack of barrels, ears pricked for gossip. Heâ€™s halfway through pilfering a string of dried fish when he overhears two dockworkers grumbling in hushed tones. â€œOrders from the top,â€ one says, glancing nervously at the palace. â€œNo one in or out without the mark. The Black Sorcererâ€™s expecting trouble.â€ Aryfisâ€™s ears perk up. The Black Sorcererâ€”Azaroth. His old master. The one whoâ€™d sent him to spy, to sabotage, to collect souls. The one whoâ€™d promised him glory and given him nothing but singed fur and a sore bottom. He creeps closer, heart thumping. The dockworkers mention a patrol, magical wards, and a â€œred-haired girlâ€ matching Sianiaâ€™s description. Aryfisâ€™s stomach drops. Azaroth knows theyâ€™re here. He darts back to the group, nearly colliding with the pirate, who grumbles and shoos him away. Siania kneels, her hand on Aryfisâ€™s shoulder, her eyes searching his face. â€œWhat is it, little one?â€ Aryfis hesitates. Old habits war with new loyalties. He could keep this to himself, earn favor with Azaroth. But Sianiaâ€™s kindness, the pirateâ€™s gruff camaraderie, the memory of the grave hoard and his own moment of heroism, hell even the fuzzy bottom 6 eyes spidersâ€”they all tug at him. He lowers his voice. â€œAzaroth knows. Heâ€™s waiting. The cityâ€™s crawling with his spies.â€ Sianiaâ€™s jaw tightens, but she nods. â€œThen we move quickly. Iâ€™ll go to the catacombs alone. You and the pirateâ€”find Agara, find the spiders. Weâ€™ll need them if weâ€™re to have any chance.â€ Aryfis puffs out his chest, trying to look brave. â€œLeave it to me, mistress! Iâ€™ll rally the spiders, the sand-walkers, the whole desert if I must!â€ He glances at the pirate, who rolls his eyes but offers a grudging nod. As Siania slips away into the cityâ€™s labyrinthine streets, Aryfis watches her go, a strange ache in his chest. Heâ€™s still a devil, still selfish, still hungry for shiny things and mischief. But for the first time, he wants something more: to be worthy of her trust. He turns to the pirate, grinning his toothiest, most impish grin. â€œWell, mate, ready to cause some trouble?â€ And with that, Aryfis the impâ€”marketplace menace, would-be soul collector, and unlikely heroâ€”leads the way into the desert, mischief and loyalty warring in his heart. (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>The Psychic Labyrinth Showdown</h2> Climax: The Psychic Labyrinth Showdown Vision 0 flying over the ancient city - a memory not your own The memory is so ancient that even the stars have shifted in the sky. Terrius, the hunterâ€™s constellation, sits further north, its familiar pattern alteredâ€”two stars, Teruis and Nova, now missing from its celestial array. It is the same city as Talon. You can tell from the layout of the islands and castle. However, other aspects of the city are altered. Some buildings are missing. No longer is the population completely human, but is mixed. Groups of elves walk in flowing robes freely, mingling pleasantries with market holders and citizens alike. In the harbour, boats connect goods from the outlying islands. Cobbled streets snake up the hill between mansions, parks, and taverns, converging at the city square, where colorful markets and a festive air announce the coming coronation. In a few days, a new king will take the throne. Overlooking all from the hilltop, the majestic castle Celnaer rests-pale marble and delicately carved columns supporting its elegant form, dashed with turrets and long halls. Flowing tiered gardens spill down from the grand ceremonial staircase, which ends at imposing gates that mark the boundary between the bustling market square and the stillness of the royal gardens. Several Crystalline towers glow with an effervescent light. They accompany the kingâ€™s road in harmony. Both styles of the elven and human are sympathetically united. Each augmenting the beauty of the other. Counterbalancing the strength of heavy and certain stones. Combined with the light pleasant filigree of details, organic and heartfelt. Achieving what would be impossible individually. The effect is awe-inspiring.. You can detect strong magic in the air. Some, directed at the towers, holding them aloft in their impossible height. Delicate swirling glyphs glint refracting rainbow eddies of colour sporadically. Along with an ambiguous sheen of deep magic murmuring deepening in its nebulous core. Other streams power the delicate fairy lights sprinkled throughout the marketplace. Some denote guilds, stone-masons, armorers, embroiderers and weavers. Others are new to you, holding symbols you can only guess at. You become aware of a harmony held within the land itself, which is no longer mute. Almost as if the land and the castle are part of a deeper intermeshed harmony. The phrase springs to your mind, ringing in your blood â€œThe song of the land.â€ The metropolis of Talin sweeps across the mainland of Alteer, its sprawl reaching out in a graceful sequence to five smaller islands, each one glimmering in the pale morning light. The islands extend outward from the peninsula, each connected to the next by slender filigree bridges that arch over the turquoise sea like delicate threads of silver. [Beneath the bridges, the ancient stonework still bears the faded sigils of the cityâ€™s founders, half-overgrown with flowering vines and moss. Here and there, weathered statues of forgotten guardians watch silently from their perches, their features softened by centuries of salt and wind.] From above, the bridges form a luminous path, weaving the city together in a shimmering line across the water. You vaguely notice the air above the sea carries not a true scent, but the faint impression of brine and the sweetness of flowering vines clinging to the bridge railings-more a memory woven into the fabric of the city than a sensation you can truly grasp, there but not there.â€¦ â€œHome..,â€ you whisper weakly. The words escape crackling and dissipating into an echoing silence.. The effort of speaking presses painfully against your ribs, the longing for those shores presses deeply like a sharp wound.. Your voice seems remote, as if left back in the cell reverberating, cold echoes against unforgiving walls. Some awareness tells you that somehow, you are in two places at the same time. A dark cold cell, and here, flooded in light. Your lips are parched and dry. You wonder if you are delirious or going mad. You let yourself drift, escaping the coldness and pain. And float above it all. Surveying it in its delicate vastness. This is how the city was before the dark times came. Yet as you drift in the memory, a quiet sense of displacement stirs within you-an uncanny awareness that these sights and feelings, vivid as they are, do not quite belong to you. Itâ€™s as if you are witnessing through anotherâ€™s eyes, their longing and hope threading through your senses, familiar yet not entirely your own. The warmth and hope of this city belong to another-someone who once called this place home, long before ruin and betrayal. A deep longing and appreciation mixed with remorse. Together, bonded for a few precious moments, you both dwell on the beauty of the scene before you-a fleeting nostalgia. You sense his caution, a wariness that lingers just beneath the surface, before the other entity flickers suddenly away from your senses.. *Notes: The only piece of Ashâ€™s true self left is his childhood core, hiding and fighting to help his daughter resist Azarothâ€™s corruption. Ashâ€™s core self is cautious, only surfacing when Azarothâ€™s attention is elsewhere.* Moving on alone, your eyes follow each jewel-like island linked along the kingâ€™s road. Tall, filigree-arched bridges span the serene turquoise sea. Large-sailed ships-bearing spices, bright silks, crates of citrus and rare woods-pass beneath, bound for distant lands, with white gulls trailing in graceful arcs, their wings flashing in the sun. You watch them, wondering if you should pursue the freedom of the open sky. The gulls call to you, offering the promise of light and adventure, inviting you to follow them into something boundless and bright, as if you might simply rise and be carried away. But something within you resists. You draw your gaze back to the island cities- and, weightless as thought, you drift downwards, unseen and untouched, gliding above rooftops and lantern-strung streets. [The rooftops themselves are a patchwork of old and new: some crowned with domes of weathered copper and others with the sharp angles of more recent repairs. In the oldest quarters, you glimpse the intricate mosaics and carved lintels that once marked the homes of honored guardians.] You pass over sunlit plazas and winding alleys, catching fragments of laughter, flashes of color, the shimmer of celebration. You hover at the edge of life, a silent observer, drawn irresistibly closer. Each island city prepares for a celebration. Paper lanterns sweep colourfully from street to street. Markets bustle, excited in activity. You notice residents scuttling hurriedly to buy scent-filled spices. Others competitively haggle for ripe fruits and exotic materials. Near shaded fountains, servants and masters alike consume cool and refreshing honey Java, all while catching the gossip of the day. Each moving back and forth through the jumbled cacophony of rambunctious merchants. Drawn by the sights below, you let yourself slip lower, gliding through the lattice of filigree bridges that link the islands in silver arcs. You sweep past the masts of anchored ships, sails snapping in the sea breeze, and thread between wheeling gulls whose wings flash bright in the sunlight. The scent of brine and citrus drifts up from the harbor as you skim above the cliffs, rising with the wind and dipping down into the winding streets. You choose a market square alive with color and sound, drifting just above washing lines and baskets of goods. Children dart between stalls, faces flushed with excitement, while merchants call out their wares, laughter and voices mingling in the air. Here, in the heart of the celebration, you hover unseen-close enough to catch every detail, yet always apart. You feel distant from them all, but appreciative of the scene. The normality and steady flow... The full flushed and gleeful faces of children, smiling merchants working and creating. Gentle hands of grandparents and carers. Simple people living good hearted lives. Yet even as you watch, a quiet ache settles in your chest-a sorrow that feels both ancient and immediate. These are not your own memories, but the bittersweet recollections of another: a ruler who once walked these streets, now left only with regret for all he could not save â€œPitiful ingrates...â€ A sharp sneer breaks your attention, rising from its previously quiet niggling at the fringes of your consciousness. The voice is bitter, heavy with old wounds and contempt-a presence both familiar and alien, as if the memory itself is haunted by a shadow that will not let go. You push it back, refusing to let it take hold. It whines as it fades: â€œThere will be consequences if you ignore me,â€ it snarls. â€œYou need me...!â€ But you feel a bright mind pressing on you, distracting you from the shrill, piercing, threatening voice. At first, you donâ€™t understand whatâ€™s happeningâ€”thereâ€™s only a sense of warmth, a flicker of presence that isnâ€™t your own. The cityâ€™s memory wavers, the laughter and color of the market fading to a hush. You sense someone beside you, a boyâ€™s presenceâ€”small, anxious, but fiercely protective. You turn, and for a heartbeat, you see him: a boy with tousled hair and wide, watchful eyes, his form shimmering at the edge of your vision. He looks at you with a mixture of hope and fear, as if heâ€™s not sure youâ€™ll recognize him. Then, Before you can speak, his shape begins to dissolve. Light spills from his edges, shimmering like mist in the morning sun. His form blurs, softening into something fluid and weightless. For a moment, he is only a glow-a luminous silhouette against the world-before the light ripples and reshapes itself. Feathers appear, not as solid things, but as strands of radiance, delicate as threads of dawn. the boy is gone, and in his place stands a seagullâ€”white and grey, delicate and bright, perched on the nearby railing. The gull cocks its head, fixing you with a sharp, intelligent gaze. For a moment, you see the echo of the boyâ€™s face in its featuresâ€”hopeful, wary, determined. He gives a soft, urgent cry, then flutters his wings, glancing back at you as if to say, â€œFollow me.â€ You do, drawn by the certainty in his movements. The gull weaves ahead, gliding low over the rooftops and winding through the narrowing streets. The cityâ€™s festive noise falls away behind you, replaced by a growing hush. The crowds thin, lanterns grow sparse, and the air grows heavier, tinged with the scent of stone and distant earth. Shadows stretch longer across the cobbles, and the laughter of the market is replaced by the quiet echo of your own footsteps. You realize youâ€™re being led somewhereâ€”somewhere important, though you donâ€™t yet know where. The gull pauses at the mouth of a narrow alley, where the cityâ€™s light gives way to a deeper gloom. The silence here is different: watchful, expectant, as if the city itself is holding its breath. The gull waits for you, unwavering, a silent promise that you are not alone, even as the way ahead grows more ominous. Bridging Passage: Entering the Labyrinth You hesitate at the mouth of the alley, the gull urging you forward. The cityâ€™s noise is a distant murmur now, muffled as if by thick fog. The alley stretches ahead, its cobbles slick with an unseen damp, the air heavy with the scent of stone and something older-ashes, perhaps, or the memory of fire. You step forward-but as you do your world shifts. The walls of the alley ripple, their surfaces shimmering like water. You feel yourself unraveling; your edges blur, your thoughts scatter. You are neither here nor there, but somewhere in between, a shadow slipping through a crack in time. The sensation is dizzying, your body light and insubstantial, as if you are a fragment of yourself inserted into a reality long past and yet impossibly present. You move, but not as you once did. You are flying, or gliding your form rippling through the city. You slip under small bridges, over cobbled roofs, past carts laden with produce, their bells chiming faintly. You weave through children at play and the marketâ€™s colorful lanterns, their laughter and chatter muted, as if heard through thick glass. But there is no music like there was beforeâ€¦.You are not wanted here. The city does not remember you, does not recognize your presence. You float-unseen, a ghost among ghosts. And yet, the land knows you somehowâ€¦faint echoes swell and ripple around youâ€¦you are needed-for what purpose, you cannot say. It pulls at you, silent, insistent, drawing you deeper into the cityâ€™s heart. The alleys narrow, the walls pressing close. The light dims, and the air grows thick with anticipation. Lanterns and laughter fade, replaced by a deepening hush. You sense the marketâ€™s vibrant life receding, the cityâ€™s festive clamor giving way to something older, quieter, more secret. Then, without warning, the ground beneath you gives way-not to darkness, but to something stranger. The cobbles dissolve, and you find yourself standing at the threshold of the labyrinth. Its corridors stretch before you, shifting and alive, every shadow a threat, every turn a test of will. Ash is beside you, his small hand finding yours. â€œYou made it,â€ he whispers, his voice trembling with relief and fear. â€œNow we have to move. Quickly or he will see usâ€¦.â€ You step forward, and the labyrinth swallows you whole. The air changes instantly-thick, electric, laced with the scent of damp stone and something older, something faintly metallic. The walls seem to breathe, shifting just beyond your vision. Shadows move, not quite shadows, more like memories given form. You and Ash move together, your hands brushing, your breaths shallow. The ground beneath you is never steady-one moment firm, the next giving way like sand. Doors flicker in and out of existence, their edges blurred as if seen through smoke. Then, a voice-Azarothâ€™s voice-slithers through the chaos, low and intimate, as if spoken directly into your mind. The words are not loud, but they cut through the noise, each syllable weighted with malice. â€œDo you like it?â€ The voice is everywhere-above you, behind you, inside your skull. â€œI made this just for you. Every corridor, every shadow. Your fears, your failures, laid bare. I know you, little ghost. I see you.â€ The walls pulse, their surfaces slick with something dark. Shadows writhe, forming shapes-faces you recognize, voices you thought youâ€™d forgotten. Azarothâ€™s laughter echoes, a sound like glass shattering. â€œYou will break just like your father didâ€¦.how patheticâ€ You try to speak, but your voice is swallowed by the maze. Azarothâ€™s presence presses closer, his words dripping with satisfaction. â€œAsh canâ€™t save you forever. Heâ€™s only a child, and children break so easily.â€ The air shifts, a cold draft curling around your ankles. The labyrinth groans, its corridors tightening. Azarothâ€™s voice drops to a whisper, intimate and cruel. â€œBut donâ€™t worry. Iâ€™ll make sure you remember this moment. Every second of it.â€ Then, silence-heavy, expectant. The labyrinth waits, and Azarothâ€™s gloating lingers in the air, a promise and a threat. You stagger, buffeted by psychic waves-images of your own failures, voices screaming, corridors collapsing. Ash is gone, his hand torn from yours. The labyrinth convulses, and for a terrible moment, you are alone, certain you will be lost here, swallowed by the maze. Ashâ€™s fingers brush your wrist-light, tentative, but steady. He doesnâ€™t speak. Instead, he moves ahead, his small frame slipping through the shadows. When the corridor splits, he hesitates only a moment before tugging you down the narrower path, his grip tightening when you flinch at the sound of something scraping behind you. He leads you under a low arch, ducking as if heâ€™s done it a hundred times before. When your foot catches on a loose cobble, he catches your arm, his breath quick but his touch firm. You see the tremor in his hand, the way his eyes dart to every movement in the dark, but he steps forward anyway, his shoulders squared. At the mouth of a dead end, he stops, listening. The air is colder here, the silence heavier. Azarothâ€™s voice rises, taunting, but Ash only sets his jaw and turns, pulling you into a crevice you hadnâ€™t noticed. He presses a finger to his lips, his eyes wide, warning you to stay silent. The corridor shudders, the walls groaning. Ash stands between you and the shifting dark, his back to you, his hands clenched at his sides. When the danger passes, he lets out a shaky breath and glances back, his expression easing when he sees you unharmed. He keeps going, keeps leading, keeps shielding you from the worst of the maze. His shoulders are tight, his breath quick, but he doesnâ€™t stop. He moves forward, and you follow. You press on, the labyrinth alive around you, every shadow a threat, every corridor a test of will. The way forward is never clear, the ground shifts, doors vanish, and the walls themselves seem to whisper your fears. Streams of psychic energy ripple through the air, carrying the stench of sickness and decay. Azaroth is everywhere and nowhere, his presence twisting the corridors, his laughter echoing in your mind. [[Vision 1: The Labyrinth and Ash]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Vision 1: The Labyrinth and Ash</h2> Vision 1: The Labyrinth and Ash You and Ash move together, hearts pounding, every sense straining for Azarothâ€™s presence. The way forward is never clear; the ground shifts, doors vanish, and the walls themselves seem to whisper your fears. Streaming, oozing psychic waves envelop youâ€”a black stench of sickness and decay that clings to your skin and seeps into your mind. Azeroth is everywhere and nowhere, his laughter echoing, his power twisting the air. Panic claws at your thoughts as paths you thought were safe dissolve into traps, your own tricks turned against you. Every step forward is met with resistance, every breath thick with dread. You press on, but Azarothâ€™s presence presses back, warping the labyrinth around you. The air pulses with psychic force, the walls closing in. You stumble, nearly falling as the ground beneath you seems to rot and ooze, threatening to swallow you whole. â€œHe canâ€™t catch us here,â€ Ash whispers, but his voice trembles. â€œOtherwise weâ€™re doomed. We have to get to the door. We have to get outâ€¦â€ He hesitates, then his voice quiets with sudden resolve. â€œNoâ€”you have to get out.â€ He squeezes your hand. â€œYou know the way now. Trust what I taught you!â€ Before you can protest, Ash darts away, his small form flickering through the psychic haze. He doesnâ€™t fight Azaroth head-onâ€”he canâ€™t. Instead, he uses every scrap of cunning he has left: darting, doubling back, creating distractions, leading Azarothâ€™s focus away from you. He appears, then vanishes, always just out of reach, always drawing the mageâ€™s attention. You feel the labyrinth shift, the pressure of Azarothâ€™s presence momentarily lessened. Ashâ€™s psychic signature is everywhereâ€”a flash of laughter, a glimmer of hope, a childâ€™s voice echoing in the maze. Azarothâ€™s rage grows, the darkness thickening as he chases after Ashâ€™s illusions. You seize the opening, pushing forward through the twisting corridors, every step a struggle against the suffocating tide. Ashâ€™s presence is a flickering guide, his bravery and selflessness lighting the way even as he grows fainter. You stumble, separated from Ash, and for a terrible moment, you are utterly alone. Doubt floods in. What if youâ€™re not strong enough? What if you fail, and all hope is lost? You force yourself to your feet, battered but unbroken, and push deeper into the maze. You reach the final doorâ€”the one youâ€™ve never been able to open. Behind you, the labyrinth convulses with Azarothâ€™s fury, but Ashâ€™s last distraction buys you the moment you need. You press your hand to the door, feeling the mark burn with purpose. Ashâ€™s voice finds you again: â€œDonâ€™t give up,â€ but heâ€™s fading, his strength gives you resolve. For a heartbeat, nothing happens. Then, with a blinding surge of light, the door shatters. The labyrinth collapses. Ash smiles at you, proud and grateful, even as he begins to fade. You stumble through the labyrinthâ€™s next threshold, and the world lurches. The air thickens, the scent of incense and old stone pressing in. Azarothâ€™s presence coils around your mind, cold and suffocating. [[Vision 1b: The Kingâ€™s Bargain (The Sword of Ages)]](set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Vision 1b: The Kingâ€™s Bargain (The Sword of Ages)</h2> Vision 1b: The Kingâ€™s Bargain (The Sword of Ages) Suddenly, you are not yourself. You are seeing through anotherâ€™s eyesâ€”your fatherâ€™s, long ago, in a secret chamber beneath the palace. The Sword of Ages rests on a black altar, its light cold and pure. The High Chancellorâ€™s voice is a blade. All are listening to the High Chancellor chant. In the blackness, his voice takes on an otherworldly quality. The words come in finality, as a pledge. An unbreakable promise. There is something about this scene, it weighs on you; you can feel a split in the fabric of it. A veil of duplicity. Not everything here is visible. You focus on the words. Paying more attention. The hue of them, the grouping. And it is there you feel the mental underlay. The memory plays, but now, as if a thin seam has opened, you sense another presenceâ€”Ash, silent, careful, threading through the vision. The scene flickers, fractionates. For a moment, you see two things at once: the surface, and the truth beneath, the meanings that slip under the skin of the words. The words echo in the chamber, but beneath each one, a second meaning coilsâ€”unspoken, poisonous, revealed only by the split in the room Ash has made. As the vision fractures, something stirs in youâ€”a faint tingling in your blood, a shiver of recognition you cannot name. The Chancellor intones, â€œI will return all that you love,â€ Broken and in torment. â€œYou will thank and worship meâ€¦â€ Regardless, you low, wretched martyr... â€œYour love of life and its continuityâ€¦â€ A canker, defiling all you treasure. â€œYour kindness wielded is a force for lightâ€¦â€ Monumental in its horror. You shall debase all you love. â€œTherefore, I treasure youâ€¦â€ Nothing could be more broken and disfigured. â€œBecause, you are like me. We are one.â€ Your vision shifts slightly to focus on the Chancellor as he intones again. â€œ... And will you, King Tharion, hold your promises given to us?â€ Tharion slumps his shoulders slightly and heavily replies, â€œThe things which I have here before promised, I will perform, and keep.â€ You can sense a silent prayer and discouragement, along with desperation. But he holds his tongue in silence. The ancient blade glows as if enraged, then fades from sight. As if it has forsaken him, or been banished. In its place a near perfect replica of the sword is placed, this sword is tainted, and will not identify the corrupt officials or followers of Severin, including now the king, within the kingâ€™s court, neither can it give the king the power to know who they are in case he would try to betray them. But the vision stutters, and in the corner of your eye, Ash moves. He is not part of the memory, but he is here, slipping between the shadows, unseen by the others. Light bends, fractionating strangely around him, a shimmer that is ethereal and fragile. He glances at you, and for a heartbeat, the walls of the chamber seem to thin. You see him press his hand to a section of stone, and a hidden compartment slides open. The true Sword of Ages gleams, untouched, hidden away. The false blade remains on the altar, its heart hollow. Ashâ€™s eyes meet yours, full of warning and sorrow. Then, as quickly as it came, the light folds back into shadow. Ash fades into the visionâ€™s edge. But Azaroth (not aware of Ashâ€™s intervention in the vision) twists the vision, forcing you to see not just the ritual, but its consequences: Tharionâ€™s hands stained with the blood of allies, the kingdomâ€™s oldest friend betrayed, chaos and war unleashed. The faces of the fallenâ€”men, women, childrenâ€”flash before you, their eyes full of accusation. Tharion stands at the center, the false sword in his grip, his face a mask of guilt and resolve. Azarothâ€™s voice slithers through the memory, cruel and triumphant: â€œHe chose this. He gave them up. He made war on his own friends, his own people. He was not trickedâ€”he was willing. This is the man you would redeem?â€ You try to look away, but the vision holds you. In the shadows at the edge of the chamber, you glimpse a small figureâ€”Ash, watching, his eyes wide and unbearably sad. He does not speak. He only watches as the pact is sealed, as your fatherâ€™s innocence is lost. There is something in his gazeâ€”a sorrow, a knowingâ€”that you cannot understand. In finality, the Lord Chancellor speaks. â€œThen it shall be as you wish...â€ â€œHe was deceived!â€ you mouth to yourself, the slight power in your voice barely vocalizes the words. A presence with deep regret can be felt but it quickly snaps off and vanishes. The voice snickers, â€œYouâ€™d like to think soâ€¦ you self-commiserating little rat. But Iâ€™ll have you knowâ€¦ such promises can only be made if they are known and agreed to! Never make deals with the devil, as it was he that invented contracts!â€ You perceive a misty form capering around you mockingly. Leaning in sharply, it whispers musically, â€œWhat he didnâ€™t know was just how much the chancellor hated him!â€¦ Memoriesâ€¦ Ahhh! So en-ter-tain-ing!â€ With several mocking flourishes, he skips off back, fading into the blackness! You stagger forward, Ashâ€™s presence lingering at your side. He does not comfort you. He only looks at you with that same, deep sadness. His eyes drop, unable to meet yours for long. His shoulders draw in, hands fidgeting at his sides, restless. For a moment, he seems to want to speak, but the words never come. Instead, he stands silent, gaze fixed somewhere just beyond you, as if weighed down by something he cannot shareâ€”not yet. You are left uncertain, shaken. Is any of this real? Am I going mad? Is it lies? Did he really betrayâ€”make war on his own friends, his own people? He was not trickedâ€”he was willing? The visionâ€™s aftertaste clings, bitter and unresolved. [[Vision 2: The Heartstone and the Queenâ€™s Return]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Vision 2: The Heartstone and the Queenâ€™s Return</h2> Vision 2: The Heartstone and the Queenâ€™s Return You are thrust into another memory, the world flickering with sickly green light. The Emperor stands over the dying Queen, his hands shaking, the air thick with incense and dread. The High Chancellor (Severin) offers him a choice: â€œServe us, and she will live. Refuse, and she dies tonight.â€ You see the Emperorâ€™s face, twisted with grief and desperation. He agrees. The ritual begins. The Queenâ€™s body is laid upon the altar, her hair fanned out like a dark halo. Severin presses the Heartstone to her chestâ€”a crystal pulsing with a hungry, unnatural light. Dark magic stirs, swirling in the incense-laden air, and the Queenâ€™s soul is drawn screaming into the stone. Her back arches, her mouth opens in a soundless cry. When her eyes snap open, they are wrongâ€”cold, empty, the warmth of her spirit stripped away. Azarothâ€™s voice hisses in your ear, venomous and triumphant: â€œHe chose this. He sacrificed her soul for his own weakness. He brought her back, knowing she would never be the same. He condemned her to a living death, all for his own selfish love. This is the man you would redeem?â€ The vision shifts. You see the Queen, alive but changed. Her laughter rings hollow in the marble halls, her touch chills the skin. The Emperor cannot meet her gaze, nor that of their daughter. He wanders the palace like a ghost, haunted by the cost of his bargain. The city grows darker, the templeâ€™s harmony broken. The Emperorâ€™s hands are stained, and the stain spreads. Rumors begin as whispers in the kitchens and servantsâ€™ quarters and among the common people: whispers of forbidden magic that brought her back but left her changed. At first, these are only hushed storiesâ€”servants glimpsing the Queenâ€™s coldness, healers noting the unnatural pallor in her eyes, old women muttering that the dead should not walk. But as the Kingâ€™s corruption deepens, these rumors become dangerous. The Kingâ€”now a puppet, his will bent by Severin and Azarothâ€”cannot bear the rumors. His pride is wounded, his shame a festering wound. He lashes out. Secret police, the Black Mantle, are formed, their faces hidden behind black steel. They move through the city at night, rooting out â€œseditionâ€ and â€œblasphemy.â€ Any mention of the Heartstone, of the Queenâ€™s unnatural state, is met with swift, brutal punishment. Neighbors turn on neighbors. Families vanish. The plazas, once filled with music and laughter, are watched by silent, armored figures. The old songs of the Queenâ€™s kindness are replaced by fearful silence. The Kingâ€™s rage is a mask for his terror. Every rumor is a reminder of his own failure, the bargain he made, the horror he unleashed. He cannot destroy the evidence in himself, so he tries to destroy it in the world. The realm becomes a place of fear and repression. The Heartstoneâ€™s true nature is buried beneath layers of lies and violence. The Queen, now a shadow, is kept out of sight. The Kingâ€™s court is a place of paranoia, where even the highest nobles fear a careless word. The cityâ€™s spirit is broken, its harmony shattered. Azaroth weaponizes these memories: â€œSee what he became? He destroyed his own people to hide his shame, visions of terrified citizens, secret police raids. He is beyond redemption.â€ But the vision stutters. The green light flickers, and suddenly Ash is beside you, his presence gentle and warm. The memory shifts, and you see what Azaroth tried to hide. The Emperor, kneeling by his wifeâ€™s bedside, his shoulders shaking with silent sobs. He presses her hand to his lips, begging the gods for any way to save her. The Queen, her voice barely a whisper, brushes his cheek. â€œLet me go. Donâ€™t bargain with darkness. I love you. Protect our daughter.â€ The Chancellorâ€™s offer comes when the Emperor is at his lowest, his mind clouded by grief and exhaustion. He hesitates, torn between hope and terror, love and fear. The ritualâ€™s true cost is hidden behind words of salvation. You see the Emperorâ€™s regret, the horror dawning in his eyes as the Queenâ€™s soul is trapped, her body left vacant, her love twisted into something cruel and unrecognizable. You see his isolation, his growing madness, his desperate attempts to make things right, all while Azarothâ€™s shadow tightens around him. Ash sits beside you, knees drawn up, his eyes wide and searching. He hugs his arms around himself, voice soft and uncertain. â€œI remember when things felt safe. When people smiled, and the halls were bright. I liked it when everyone was kind. But thenâ€¦ people started whispering. They said things about herâ€”things that made everything feel heavy and sad. I didnâ€™t like it. I wanted it to stop.â€ He looks down, fingers twisting in his sleeves. â€œI donâ€™t understand why it all changed. The kingâ€¦ he stopped smiling. He got so quiet. He loved her. He loved you, and then got so angry. I just wanted everyone to be good again. I wanted the bad things to go away. I wanted to help, but I didnâ€™t know how. I justâ€¦ wanted things to be gentle, like before.â€ Ashâ€™s hand finds yours, small and warm. He says nothing more, but his sadness settles over you like a blanket. Ash is the Emperorâ€™s innocence and kindness, but heâ€™s been separated so long that he experiences the â€œkingâ€ as someone else, almost like a sibling or a distant self. Sianiaâ€™s Realization The weight of both visions presses on your heart. You see your father not as a monster, but as a manâ€”flawed, desperate, manipulated. Once, perhaps, he was capable of love and regret, but now you cannot be sure. The man you remember is lost somewhere behind the shadows and the madness. You donâ€™t know if anything of him remains, or if forgiveness is even possible. Over time, rumors spread among the commoners about a â€œQueenâ€™s soul stone,â€ but no one knows the truth. The Heartstoneâ€™s existence is actively covered up by Severin, the Emperor, and his agents; any mention of it is suppressed, and its true nature is lost to all but a select few. You look at the Heartstone in your hand, the Queenâ€™s soul silent for now, what so many lives were lost overâ€”in suffering, all products of Faustian bargains. Grateful for the small, warm hand in yours, Ash resolutely sits beside you, his presence comforting. Whatever else is true, you are not alone in this place. For now, that is enough. [[Inside the Mind: The Undoing]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Inside the Mind: The Undoing</h2> Inside the Mind: The Undoing (Atmospheric Psychic Battle) You cross the threshold into the final room of the labyrinth, and the world shudders. The air is thickâ€”almost viscousâ€”heavy with the scent of old incense and the chill of centuries-old regret. Shadows pool in the corners, swirling with the memory of loss. You alone are alive here; every other presence is memory, echo, or spirit. The Emperor sits hunched at the center, his outline flickering between flesh and aether, as if heâ€™s caught between worlds. Azarothâ€™s presence is a living darkness, putrid and sliding along the walls, casting long, unnatural shadows that seem to whisper and writhe. The Heartstone in your hands shimmers with gentle warmth. A glimmer of silver mist curls from the delicate wood, swirling in the charged air. Then, as if the room itself is holding its breath, the light gathers and lengthens, weaving itself into the suggestion of a figure. A silvery, translucent form unfurlsâ€”robed in flowing light, her presence both impossibly delicate and unyielding. Her feet barely touch the ground. It is your mother: ethereal, luminous, more beautiful and sorrowful than any memory or dream. For a heartbeat, you can only stare, knowing this is the first time you have truly seen her. When she speaks, the air shivers with the memory of spring and the scent of roses. Azeroth (soft, insidious; his words chill the air, the shadows lengthening): â€œSheâ€™s come to judge you, you know. Thereâ€™s a note of confidence, but beneath it, a subtle tremor. His grip is absolute, but not unbreakable. The walls drip with spectral ooze, and flickers of the Emperorâ€™s worst memories bleed through the air. Mother (ethereal, voice gentle but sorrowful): â€œThatâ€™s not true. I never wanted to judge you. I loved you, even when I saw the danger in your choices. I warned you because I cared, not because I wished to shame you. I came because youâ€™re more than what heâ€™s made you believe.â€ Her words float like music, layered with a quiet strengthâ€”the sound of distant bells and the soft rush of wind through leaves. The cold recedes, replaced by a golden glow. Memories of laughter and sunlight flicker at the edges of your visionâ€”a forest in bloom, hope almost tangible. Warmth gently pushes back against Azarothâ€™s chill. You (quiet, steady; your living breath stirs the dust, grounding the space): â€œHeâ€™s always tried to turn us against each other. He made you believe you were alone, that youâ€™d lost her trust. But she loved youâ€”even when she disagreed, even when she was afraid.â€ Your voice is hesitant at first, but grows firmer as you see the effect your words have. The dust stirs with every breath you take, and the labyrinthâ€™s walls ripple in uncertainty. You sense, for the first time, that your presence matters. Emperor (voice hollow, uncertain; his form flickers, the crystal spreading as his doubt grows): â€œIâ€¦ I tried to protect you. I tried to protect her. But everything went wrong. But nothing turned out as I hoped.â€ His words come in broken fragments, sometimes clear, sometimes warped and distant, as if spoken from underwater. Frost creeps across the floor, regret weighing the air. Yet thereâ€™s a flicker of longingâ€”a yearning for something better. Azeroth (offended, almost hurt; the darkness pulses, pressing in): â€œYou asked for deliverance. You pleaded for protection. I gave you what you wishedâ€”your army preserved, your enemies at bay. You feel the pressure in your skull, as if the room itself resents the lack of gratitude. Azeroth's tone is sharper, more brittle, as if the lack of gratitude wounds him. I never stopped loving you, even when I feared what you were becoming.â€ Her light pushes back the gloom, illuminating the cracks in the crystal, creating a path of light through the darknessâ€”a memory of what might have been. The Emperorâ€™s form glimmers faintly, as if remembering hope. Azeroth (mocking; his voice multiplies, echoing from every shadow): â€œSee? Even she doubted you. And he admits it. Weakness. Guilt. Thatâ€™s all he is. Thatâ€™s all heâ€™ll ever be. [[Ashâ€™s Return: The Catalyst]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Ashâ€™s Return: The Catalyst</h2> While Azarothâ€™s attention is fixed on you and your mother, a golden light flickers at the edge of your visionâ€”a ripple in the psychic haze. You sense, rather than see, a small presence slip into the room: Ash, silent, eyes wide with exhaustion and resolve. Shadows cling to him like mist, but his gaze is fixed not on you, but on the Emperor. Ash closes his eyes, steadying himself. He doesnâ€™t speak; he doesnâ€™t need to. You feel the brush of his hand in yoursâ€”real and not real at once, a memory, a promise, a final act of courage. The Emperor sees him. For a moment, neither moves. Then Ash lifts his hand. The Emperor, jaw set, mirrors him. Their palms meet. Where their hands touch, light pulses outwardâ€”silver and gold, flickering with memories and lost time. Heâ€™d flinch at the same nightmares that haunted the Emperor, and sometimes heâ€™d whisper old wordsâ€”private phrases, childhood promisesâ€”you once overheard the Emperor mutter in his sleep. Ash never seemed to age, even as the years blurred in the labyrinth. He spoke with a wisdom that belonged to someone much older, yet sometimes shrank from the world like a frightened boy. Sometimes, youâ€™d catch Ash watching the Emperor from afar, his small face shadowed by a sadness far beyond his years. He never tried to approach, never tried to be seen; it was as if he knew the Emperor could not see him, or would not. There was a heaviness in Ashâ€™s gaze, a silent understanding that there was no way to save the Emperor from himself. Whenever you witnessed this, it always felt strangeâ€”at odds with everything you thought you knew about the boy. You didnâ€™t know why, but the sight unsettled you, as if you were glimpsing a truth just out of reach. But none of thisâ€”none of Ashâ€™s cleverness, his hiding, his hopeâ€”would have been enough. Ash isnâ€™t just a wandering spirit. He is something the Emperor lostâ€”or hidâ€”long ago. Something precious, uncorrupted, and deeply familiar. Ash glances at you. For the first time, you see not just a boy, but a memory made realâ€”an echo of innocence, courage, and love. He smiles, brave and sad, and in that look you see both gratitude and farewell. And you understand: this is goodbye. Now, as the light between Ash and the Emperor grows, the world seems to hold its breath. Their hands meetâ€”childâ€™s and manâ€™sâ€”and light pulses outward, silver and gold, flickering with memories and lost time. For a single heartbeat, their faces blur and merge: child and man, innocence and sorrow, hope, forgiveness and regret, all fusing into one. Then the light intensifies, and Ashâ€™s form dissolves completelyâ€”not vanishing, but becoming indistinguishable from the Emperor, as if the two have always been one being, finally made whole. The light flares, and Ashâ€™s form dissolves into the Emperor, merging in a rush of memory and feeling. The Emperor straightens, shoulders squaring, his presence suddenly commanding. He looks down at his hand, then at the space where Ash stood. His voice, when it comes, is steady, but thereâ€™s a quiet tremor beneath the words. â€œHe was what I hid from Azaroth,â€ he says. â€œThe last of what I was before the darkness took hold. When I knew I was losing myself, I split my mind. I sent him awayâ€”my hope, my innocenceâ€”so that something good might survive, even if I did not.â€ He lifts his head, and for the first time, you see a new steadiness in his eyesâ€”a warmth that wasnâ€™t there before. And in that gaze, you recognize something else: a deep, grateful recognition of the journey you both endured, side by side, in the shadowed catacombs. The Emperorâ€™s expression softens, and for a moment, you can still see a glimmer of Ash thereâ€”a trace of the friend you never expected to find in your father. â€œFor so long, I thought I was lost. Now, at last, I am whole. And I am free.â€ The chamber is silent, the light gentle and whole. In that hush, you understand: Ash and the Emperor were never truly separate. The childâ€™s courage and the manâ€™s sorrow are one and the sameâ€”and now, at last, they are whole again. [[Chapter 46: The Final Confrontation]](set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)The Arranged Marriage The counselors, now controlling the corrupted Tharion, arrange for his daughter to marry a cruel partner They target her because of her mother's bloodline, which is the one connected to the temple The corrupted Tharion, now completely evil, approves of this arrangement This planned marriage becomes the catalyst for the protagonist's escape and the beginning of the main story â€œI died.., I am sure it is so.â€ She scans back to her last memories, although clouded... She mouths to herself. â€œBut it cannot be.â€ Aelira tries to calm her thoughts. Reaching for the princess, she holds her gently, tucking in the soft woollen blanket. Attempting to rock them both to sleep. Failing, she continues to stare into the night silently, swaying back and forth. And Aelira... something is wrong with Aelira. She moves differently, speaks differently. Sometimes he catches her staring at their daughter with an expression he cannot name but that chills his blood. When he confronts her, she smiles in a way that doesn't reach her eyes and speaks of being "merely tired." [[Rebirth of the moon]]<Notes to self Rebirth of the moon: The queen has a night mare, and realises she had died But doesnt yet realisewhat has happend, Tharion deal etc, but instead worries she may be losing her mind> It is the day of the coronation. A small peasant boy runs smiling at her. In his hands a hidden gift which he imparts to her wordlessly, with solemn innocence. She opens her cupped hands to reveal a small dead bird. In shock she looks up, back to the boy. He studies her face with sadness. His eyes dark and wise, aged with care.., seemingly at congruities with such a young body. They sparred until their muscles screamed, traded insults with grins, fought side by side in the wastes beyond the walls. (text-colour:#d0af53)[The First Step of Kinship] Despite the guardsâ€™ silence and inaction, Torren felt a surge of protectiveness. Though loyal to these men, he was compelled to stand by her. Torren's defiance that dayâ€”an eight-year-old boy shielding a frightened six-year-old exile when no one else wouldâ€”marked the first crack in the fort's indifference. Back then, he hadn't thought of it as courage. He had just been a child himself, reacting to the raw injustice of her exile. But that instinctive act had become the foundation of something unshakable. To the Order of Severin, they had been nothing - a nameless orphan and the disgraced daughter of a condemned house, already expunged from official records in a remote outpost the world had forgotten. Torren's childish defiance meant nothing against the machinery of Order's justice. Yet as the years hardened them both, the truth had become undeniable. He had been her stubborn protector even when he could barely lift a training sword. She had become the sister of his heart long before either understood what that bond would demand. (text-colour:#d0a853)[How does Torren use his influence during the race?] <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[He runs ahead with the others, she's not part of their circle.]] </span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[He slows to run beside Siania]] </span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[He calls out sharply to the boys, ordering them to wait for Siania]] </span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>Roots in the Desert</h2> Siania cherished the stories of that ancient strife above all, her voice hushed with reverence as she touched the altered ground, as if her exile and unspoken magic tied her to its wounds. Still, I feel the weight of not standing with her.â€ Torrenâ€™s jaw tightened, a rare edge slipping through. â€œHard odds, yes. But not like this. No blades or sandâ€”just schemes we canâ€™t counter.â€ Jaro met his gaze, resolute. â€œShe wonâ€™t stand alone if this trial proves her worth. Letâ€™s hope it wins her strong allies.â€ Torren exhaled, the tension easing a fraction. â€œWeâ€™ll see her through this much, at least.â€ Jaroâ€™s smirk returned, a quiet determination beneath it. â€œOur little foxâ€”sheâ€™ll outwit them yet.â€ Torren gave a slight nod, a trace of warmth buried beneath his reserve. â€œYour optimism is a constant, Jaro.â€ Jaroâ€™s smirk deepened, though it carried no malice. â€œA necessary counterweight to your gravity, Iâ€™d wager.â€ He fell into step beside Torren, his easy stride a contrast to Torrenâ€™s measured pace, yet both were bound by shared years and the unspoken weight of what lay ahead. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Pride Tinged with Sorrow]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>Pride Tinged with Sorrow</h2> A quiet pride stirred in Torrenâ€™s composed exterior. Sianiaâ€™s strengths would holdâ€”he had no doubt. In her, they recognized resilience and skill. This trial, part of "The Passing" at Fort Kezarak, was more than a challenge. It was a defining moment. Held in the emperorâ€™s remote desert stronghold, it was a private event. Soldiers rose in rank there, while Noble Houses backed fighters and gained prestige. As a rule, the emperor kept his distance, with the Order of Severin dispatching mere Adjudicators to collect taxes, never their Hyrach. But now, the entire court descended upon the fort. Their presence lent weight to the occasion and created tension in the fort. The gathered nobility brought poisonings and political schemes, though most soldiers ignored these intrigues. For Siania, heir to the emperor, the stakes reached far beyond the arena. This moment aligned with the emperorâ€™s decision to reclaim his child to court to strengthen his reign, a rare and significant act, the reason for the courtâ€™s attendance. Torren, though sharp and observant, knew little of the deeper reasonsâ€”out here in this isolated outpost, under the emperorâ€™s strict control, news was scarce, with only fragments slipping through from supply caravans. He hoped Sianiaâ€™s performance would earn her the recognition she deserved, proving her worth not just as a warrior but as a figure of strength in this pivotal transition. Yet beneath that pride, a bittersweet undercurrent persisted. Success meant her return to the capital, ending her time among them, and the fort would lose a vital part of itself. Still, Torren wished she would winâ€”not just for her sake, but so her success could protect her and win allies at court, carrying Kezarakâ€™s values to a place that desperately needed them. The clang of steel and the roar of the crowd grew louder as they descended from the ramparts, the sounds rising to meet them like a tide. Torrenâ€™s eyes lingered on the arena below. â€œCome on, she doesnâ€™t waste a move. If she wins, itâ€™ll be quick and cleanâ€”we donâ€™t want to miss it. The only ones who should be sweating are House Krenâ€™s tracker and the judges, trying to keep up. So stop worrying.â€ Tarek joined them, his nod carrying quiet assurance. â€œSheâ€™ll have to end it before he can wear her downâ€”precision over brute force, as always.â€ He clapped Jaroâ€™s shoulder, tone steady. â€œAccuracy is her edge.â€ Jaro tossed him a waterskin. â€œTarekâ€™s got three silver on her disarming Krenâ€™s man. I say heâ€™ll make her work for itâ€”heâ€™s not easy to catch off guard.â€ Torrenâ€™s lips quirked into a rare smile. â€œEither way, itâ€™ll be a match worth watching. Sheâ€™s always known how to find the smallest opening.â€ He nodded toward the crowded gates, where the crowd pressed close. â€œIs Vestergaard here to survey the field?â€ <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Next|Light Words, Heavy Thoughts]] </span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Light Words, Heavy Thoughts</h2> Jaro gave a low huff, eyes narrowing with dry amusement. â€œSurveying, indeed. He watches the yard as a hawk eyes open groundâ€”though I reckon itâ€™s not just her blade heâ€™s keen to know, given the betrothal.â€ Tarekâ€™s eyes sharpened, a protective edge beneath his calm. A brief smirk crossed Torrenâ€™s face, fleeting but pointed. â€œHard to fault him. A talent like hers? Heâ€™s likely never seen a woman rival him in the trialâ€™s sword formsâ€”even if itâ€™s just drills, not real fighting.â€ Jaro leaned closer, voice low with a conspiratorial tone. â€œI doubt itâ€™s those particular â€˜formsâ€™ that hold his interest.â€ Torrenâ€™s elbow nudged sharply, his look cutting. â€œMind yourself, Jaro. Thatâ€™s Siania. Show some respect.â€ Jaro lifted a hand in mock surrender, smirk fading under Torrenâ€™s firm gaze, the quip carrying more weight than meant, tinged with a shared, quiet envy they all had for the man whoâ€™d claim their closest companion. Tarek muttered, â€œHeâ€™s probably just hoping sheâ€™ll save him from his mother.â€ The three diffused snorted almost in unison. Jaro shook his head. â€œGods, picture it. Our little fox staring down Lady Vestergaard at breakfast.â€ He tried to mimic Sianiaâ€™s glare, earning a crooked smile from Torren. Jaroâ€™s tone grew shadowed. â€œLady Vestergaardâ€™s ruthlessness isnâ€™t mere gossipâ€”sheâ€™s a mother-in-law you donâ€™t defy. Youâ€™ve heard the stories.â€ He gave a slight shudder, leaving the rest unspoken. (text-colour:#c0975f)[''A Deeper Concern''] Tarekâ€™s grin flashed again, undeterred. â€œGood that Sianiaâ€™s training then, useful for a real fight.â€ Torren shook his head, still chuckling. â€œVestergaardâ€™d trade every ancestral sword in his house for that.â€ Jaroâ€™s fingers drummed on the hilt at his side. â€œWe might yet hold him to that.â€ â€œShould he ever need steelâ€”â€ Tarek began, but Jaro cut him off, voice dropping low. â€œVestergaard can swing a sword well enoughâ€”both of them canâ€”but his mother rules the court, a far deadlier battlefield than any tourney ground. He may be a capable fighter, but heâ€™s ill-prepared to shield Siania from the games sheâ€™ll face there.â€ The group fell silent. <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Next|A Procession of Power]] </span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>A Procession of Power</h2> They moved steadily down the road, the crowds thickening with every step. Merchants hawked their wares from colorful stalls, their calls weaving through the air alongside the scent of spiced meats and fresh bread. Festive banners in Lucial colours fluttered overhead, and laughter mingled with the clatter of boots on stone. Yet beneath the surface buzz, a tension hummedâ€”an undercurrent of anticipation that tightened as they neared the arena gates. Then it cameâ€”a jarring clash of iron bells, joined by the steady thud of sand-worn feet. Their words fell silent, a ripple of stillness spreading outward. Torren, Jaro, and Tarek slowed their pace; the street itself seemed to tense. Eyes turned. From the glare emerged the palanquin. It moved with a somber grandeur, lacquered panels glinting like newly drawn blades, silk drapes in crimson and gold catching the light. Indentured porters, ribs visible beneath tattered livery, bore its weight with faltering steps. Each movement was urged by thin, jeweled lashes in the hands of junior acolytes; every strike left a mark, drew a stifled cry, andâ€”more chillinglyâ€”a forced â€œthank youâ€ from the one struck. Some nobles along the path wore masks of detachment, though unease betrayed them in fleeting glances, while others watched with revulsion they dared not voice. Officers, bound by duty, remained expressionless. Merchants turned their gaze aside, feigning ignorance. Soldiers stood rigid and silent, their faces a mix of anger and shame, held in check by discipline. Sadaarkian nobles observed with stiff approval or barely concealed discomfort, shown in tightened lips or subtle shifts of gaze. Their courtesans, faces partly veiled by painted fans, murmured softly, their expressions unreadable as they navigated the undercurrents of courtly games. Lucian officers from other participating forts, clad in their houseâ€™s colors, stood unyielding, their neutrality a shield, though a hint of resentment might flicker in their eyes. Allegiant officers, the emperor's elite, dressed in black, upheld flawless discipline, faces blank, yet brief, almost imperceptible glances passed among them. Envoys, ever observant, cataloged each reaction, their own visages carefully empty to avoid any misstep. At the center sat Morvaine, Thrice-Scarred Hierophant of the Order of Severin. His skin bore the marks of ceremonial brands across his bare scalp, each scar threaded with black opal. He reclined on velvet cushions, one gaunt hand gripping an iron crozier, the other idly tracing a rosary of finger-bones. Around him gathered scarlet-robed hierarchs, laden with rings, reliquaries, and the cloying scent of attar meant to cover traces of old blood. They chanted litanies of self-denial, even as they surrounded themselves with gem-studded opulence. Behind them followed novices in plain cincture and linenâ€”young, earnest, still believing in a sacred purpose. They marched in step, unaware of the records of bribes and tithes swelling Morvaineâ€™s coffers or the dungeons hidden beneath his sanctuaries. The higher one rose in Severin, the more shadowed the paths became; innocence was stripped away layer by layer. The procession pressed forward, a tangible force of sanctioned harshness pushing legionaries to the roadside. A single nod from Morvaine prompted an acolyte to lash a porter with greater force, the whip's crack splitting the air. Dust blended with incense; blood dotted the heated stone. (text-colour:#c0975f)[''How does Torren react?''] <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Silently Endure]] </span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Offer a Quiet Support.]]</span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Shield Jaro's Expression]]</span>(set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>Days of Innocence 2</h2> Once the wagons were empty, they'd huddle in the blue shade by the courtyard wall, the driver weaving stories of pirates, whirlpools, and true khamsin with feigned exasperation and real warmth. Their knack for turning anything into a game was evident in how they jostled for the best listening spot near the unloading area. As the afternoon waned and the shadows grew longer, the mood shifted. The ancient tales quieted themâ€”accounts of mage wars that had shattered what was once an idyllic realm. From where they sat, the children could see the distant silhouette of Fort Kezarakâ€™s southwestern flank, where the walls merged with the Great Cliff. Its sheer face was carved with a deep incision, running straight down to the base, scarring the wall and bursting into the pockmarked, blistered sand below. There, deep obsidian shards still shone from the heat that had turned it into glassâ€”the marks of the sorcery that had created the Mage Sands. Where rivers once cut through green valleys and forests stretched to the horizon, now only fissures, sinkholes, and crystallized sand drifts remainedâ€”scars of betrayal and power. Torren remembered the driverâ€™s eyes glinting as he spoke of a Neâ€™Tiriania mage who had fallen there. He looked at Siania as if seeing her own legacy in the story. The driver called it a final standâ€”a desperate defense of the land where her ancestors once raised their banners. House Neâ€™Tiriania later fled to Talin, abandoning their home in the old southern palace and Fort Kezarak, which was eventually claimed by the Emperor under Lucian rule. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Stories Roots in the desert]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <h2>He runs ahead with the others, she's not part of their circle.</h2> The others follow without hesitation, their pace quickening as Torren leads. He's always been the fastest, the one to follow, some think, falling into step. Siania stays behind, the space between her and the group growing. //She's different,// others murmur, watching her. The distance feels natural to some, but to others, the absence weighs heavier than before. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Arrive at carravan]]</span> <!--Stories Roots in the desert--> (set: $torren to it - 1, $jaro to it - 1, $tarek to it - 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it - 1) (set: $notificationMessage to "-1 Fort Kezerak, Jaro and Tarek disapprove") (display: "Notification") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>He slows to run beside Siania</h2> The painted wagons of the storytellers' caravan beckoned in the distance. Torren, usually the first to race ahead, matched his stride to Siania's. Her small legs worked hard to keep up, her face bright with the effort. He offered no words, no grand gesture, just a steady presence. The other boys, drawn to Torren's quiet strength, eased their pace without being told. A few glanced at Siania, noticing the determination in her face, the way she struggled to keep up. A flicker of understanding passed between them. //Maybe she's not so bad//, one seemed to think. //Torren's looking out for her.// The wagons still promised treats and tales, but the race had subtly transformed into a shared journey, one where Siania now had a place. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Arrive at carravan]]</span> <!--Stories Roots in the desert--> (set: $helpedSiania to true) (set: $torren to it + 1, $jaro to it + 1, $tarek to it + 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it + 1) (set: $notificationMessage to "+1 Fort Kezerak, Jaro and Tarek approve, Ran with the fox") (display: "Notification") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<h2>He calls out sharply to the boys, ordering them to wait for Siania..</h2> His voice cuts through the air, firm and unyielding. //He's always got to be in charge//, some think, bristling at the command. The group halts abruptly, eyes flicking between one another and Torren. //Why does he always have to make it a thing? //others wonder, resenting the forced situation. The children's own sense of choice is overridden. Siania stands caught in the middleâ€”pulled forward by his command, yet uneasy with the attention it draws. She didn't ask for this, some realize, feeling a mix of pity and resentment. Friendships arenâ€™t something to be commanded, and the weight of his authority leaves a tension that lingers long after the race resumes. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Arrive at carravan]]</span> <!--Stories Roots in the desert--> (set: $torren to it + 1, $jaro to it + 1, $tarek to it + 1, $fortKezerakApproval to it + 2) (set: $notificationMessage to "+2 Fort Kezerak, Jaro and Tarek approve") (display: "Notification") (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)(display: "Header") (link: "Back")[(go-to: (history:
