</tr> <tr class="neutral"> <td>Jaro</td> <td>(print: $jaro)</td> <td>(print: $jaroAllies)</td> <td>(print: $jaroEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="neutral"> <td>Tarek</td> <td>(print: $tarek)</td> <td>(print: $tarekAllies)</td> <td>(print: $tarekEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="neutral"> <td>Siania</td> <td>(print: $siania)</td> <td>(print: $sianiaAllies)</td> <td>(print: $sianiaEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="neutral"> <td>Torren</td> <td>(print: $torren)</td> <td>(print: $torrenAllies)</td> <td>(print: $torrenEnemies)</td> </tr> <!-- Independent Faction --> <tr class="independent"> <td rowspan="3">Independent</td> <td>Halak</td> <td>(print: $halak)</td> <td>(print: $halakAllies)</td> <td>(print: $halakEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="independent"> <td>Arafis</td> <td>(print: $arafis)</td> <td>(print: $arafisAllies)</td> <td>(print: $arafisEnemies)</td> </tr> <tr class="independent"> <td>Draethlyn</td> <td>(print: $draethlyn)</td> <td>(print: $draethlynAllies)</td> <td>(print: $draethlynEnemies)</td> </tr> </table> </div> <div class="custom-panel-row"> <div class="custom-panel-item"> <div class="panel-text">Lucian Empire</div> <div class="panel-icon button-icon"> [[<img src="https://alathean.weebly.com/uploads/5/1/4/9/51493641/talon_orig.jpg" alt="Passage One Icon" style="width:100%; height:auto;">->Lucian Empire]] </div> </div> <div class="custom-panel-item"> <div class="panel-text">Diplomat</div> <div class="panel-icon button-icon"> [[<img src="https://alathean.weebly.com/uploads/5/1/4/9/51493641/house-sabla-small_orig.png" alt="Passage Two Icon" style="width:100%; height:auto;">->Passage Two]] </div> </div> <div class="custom-panel-item"> <div class="panel-text">Loyalist</div> <div class="panel-icon button-icon"> [[<img src="https://alathean.weebly.com/uploads/5/1/4/9/51493641/housekrensm_orig.png" alt="Passage Three Icon" style="width:100%; height:auto;">->Passage Three]] </div> </div> </div><h1>The Lucian Empire: A Realm of Faith and Power</h1> <div style="margin-bottom: 1em;"> <h2 style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;">The Order of Severin</h2> The empire is deeply shaped by the Order of Severin, a powerful religious organization that controls not only spiritual life but also the economy, trade, and social order. The Orderâ€™s influence is visible everywhere: from the scarred clergy who enforce their will, to the public rituals that blend spectacle with terror. The people of the empire live under constant watch. The nobility navigate a treacherous world of alliances and betrayals, while common folk endure heavy taxes and strict obedience. Festivals and ceremonies are both a celebration and a reminder of the Orderâ€™s dominance. The Order claims to be the inheritors and protectors of the Temple, a sacred site of immense importance to the Lucian empire. However, this claim is fiercely contested by loyalists who believe the true guardianship belongs elsewhere. This ongoing struggle for legitimacy adds a layer of tension beneath the surface of the empireâ€™s rigid order. </div> <div style="margin-bottom: 1em;"> <h2 style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;">Economy and Daily Life</h2> The Order of Severin monopolizes much of the empireâ€™s wealth and resources. Land is controlled by the Order or loyal nobles, and peasants work under harsh conditions. Trade is tightly regulated, with travel permits required and â€œtaintedâ€ goods confiscated. Despite this, the cities bustle with artisans, merchants, and travelers. Markets offer fine textiles, wines, and crafts, especially from regions influenced by the Sadaarkian culture, known for their precision and beauty. Be cautiousâ€”spies and informants are common, and even casual conversations can be overheard. The Silver Mark is the common currency, and while Common is widely spoken, knowing some Sadaarkian can be advantageous, especially when dealing with merchants or nobles. </div> <div style="margin-bottom: 1em;"> <h2 style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;">The Sadaarkian Influence</h2> The Sadaarkian culture shapes many aspects of the empire, particularly the north western regions. It is a culture defined by ruthless pragmatism and strict social order, where strength and cunning are prized above all. Those influenced by the Sadaarkian culture are trained from childhood in intrigue and survival, making them formidable allies or dangerous enemies. Marriages and alliances are carefully arranged, and compassion is often seen as a liability. In cities like Talon, the capital of this influence, order and cleanliness are paramount, and public displays of emotion are rare among the elite. </div> <div style="margin-bottom: 1em;"> <h2 style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;">Sadaarkian Education and Training</h2> From a young age, boys destined for the military are separated from their families at six years old to begin a grueling ascent into military life. They are sent to remote, austere forts where survival is as much a test of will as of skill. These forts, infamous for their harsh conditions and relentless training, forge the youth into disciplined warriors, schooled in combat, strategy, and endurance. For nearly two decades, these young trainees live under constant scrutiny and rigorous discipline, enduring physical hardship and mental trials designed to weed out weakness and cultivate resilience. Upon reaching maturity around the age of twenty-four, they return not to their family homes but to local barracks, where they serve as elite soldiers and guardians of Sadaarkian order. This prolonged separation and harsh upbringing create a warrior caste deeply loyal to the state and steeped in a culture that values control, calculated ruthlessness, and unwavering obedience to the nobles they serve. In contrast, the nobles receive a comprehensive education that includes politics, intrigue, and the martial arts, preparing them to lead and govern. This education emphasizes strategic thinking, diplomacy, and the subtle arts of manipulation, ensuring that they are well-equipped to navigate the complex web of alliances and betrayals that define noble life. </div> <div style="margin-bottom: 1em;"> <h2 style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;">Safety and Advice for Visitors</h2> Visitors should remain vigilant, especially in crowded markets and less-patrolled areas. Pickpockets and skilled thieves operate in busy areas, so keep valuables close and avoid displaying wealth. While rare, poisoning is a known risk in Sadaarkian intrigue, so never accept food or drink from strangers, and be cautious at unfamiliar gatherings. Report any suspicious activity to the city watch, who are generally visible and responsive in public areas. </div> <div style="margin-bottom: 1em;"> <h2 style="margin-bottom: 0.2em;">Final Thoughts</h2> The Lucian Empire is a land of stark contrastsâ€”beauty and brutality, faith and fear, loyalty and betrayal. For those who navigate its complexities with care, it offers rich culture, powerful allies, and deep history. For the unwary, it can be a place of ruin and despair. </div> <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span>Passage Two <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span>Passage Three <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span> <div id="allegiance-table"> <h3>Ã‚lathean Decoder Table</h3> <p style="text-align: center; font-style: italic; margin-bottom: 1em;"> <div class="panel-heading">ð‘¤ ð‘¤‚ð‘¥„ð‘¤¤ð‘¤±ð‘¤¤ð‘¤±ð‘¤¬ð‘¤½ð‘¤Œð‘¤±ð‘¤›ð‘¤³ð‘¤ ð‘¤Ÿð‘¤½ð‘¤Žð‘¤µ<br></div> "Ã‚lathean Ne' TÃ®rainian es et ne khÃ¢m, en' are' nedarin Ã¢ sul" </p> <table> <thead> <tr> <th>Word / Phrase</th> <th>Meaning / Function</th> <th>Notes / Explanation</th> <th>Example / Comment</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td><em>Full Phrase:</em> Ã‚lathean Ne' TÃ®rainian es et ne khÃ¢m, en' are' nedarin Ã¢ sul</td> <td>Overall Meaning</td> <td> Blessed with elven blood, the Noble House of TÃ®rain exists now and will continue to exist. It endures at its core. The legend says TÃ®rainâ€™s greatness will return. It is destiny. Power may rest for a time but will rise again to restore the rightful order. This is the lasting promise of House TÃ®rain, held by its loyal followers. </td> <td>Motto of Loyalists to House TÃ®rainian</td> </tr> <tr> <td>Ã‚lathean</td> <td>Graced with elven blood</td> <td>Adjective</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>Ne'</td> <td>The noble</td> <td>Article + noun marker</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>TÃ®rainian</td> <td>(of) TÃ®rain</td> <td>Noun</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>es</td> <td>is</td> <td>Verb</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>et</td> <td>and</td> <td>Conjunction</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>ne</td> <td>not / negation</td> <td>Particle</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>khÃ¢m</td> <td>Not (yet), but (will be)</td> <td>Particle; expressing negation with an implied future change or return; can also be used as a response indicating a task is not yet complete but will be</td> <td>"Sis, you load all the boxes?" "KhÃ¢m" (Not yet, but I will)</td> </tr> <tr> <td>en'</td> <td>and / the</td> <td>Contraction</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>are'</td> <td>are</td> <td>Verb</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>nedarin</td> <td>enduring</td> <td>Adjective</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>Ã¢</td> <td>to / in / of</td> <td>Preposition</td> <td></td> </tr> <tr> <td>sul</td> <td>soul / essence / legacy</td> <td>Noun</td> <td></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </div><H2>Torren claims the best spoils, enjoying the rewards of leadership.</H2> Torren takes all the sweets and demands his favourite stories for himself, ignoring Siania and the boys. (display: "Notification") (set: $fortKezerakApproval to it - 1, $jaro to it - 1, $tarek to it - 1) <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<H2>Torren only shares with Siania.</H2> He remembered the way his arm had felt around Siania's small shoulders that day, how he'd automatically given her the biggest piece of candy. "You deserve something nice," he'd said, as if a sugar treat could replace belonging. The other boys had shuffled their feet. He'd noticed that much, though he hadn't cared to decipher their glances at the time. They didn't dislike Siania - she was just a little thing - but something had changed. Before, they'd all played the game together. He would lead the haggling, spinning wild stories while the others jumped in, their combined efforts turning worthless stones into treasures. But that day, he hadn't even looked up when the wagon arrived. No bargaining happened. No shared victory. The boys had still gathered, but without his usual banter, the driver had simply tossed them a few pitiful sweets before moving on. Only later did Torren understand what he'd taken from them - from all of them. The memory burned now. He'd taken the easy path - showering Siania with individual attention instead of doing the harder work of weaving her into their group. A real leader would have found a way to make her part of their hustle, to let her shine while keeping the crew whole. Instead, he'd broken their rhythm and called it kindness. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span> (set: $notificationMessage to "The boys resent Torren's favoritism. No approval gained.") (display: "Notification") (set: $fortKezerakApproval to it + 1, $jaro to it - 1, $tarek to it - 1) (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <H2>Torren brings Siania into the game.</H2> Torrenâ€™s grin was all mischief as he nudged Siania forward. â€œAlright, little fox, youâ€™re in.â€ Whenever the grizzled old driver visited the fort, the boys swarmed his wagon, hawking scavenged desert stones and begging for stories. Most were common trinketsâ€”junk the wastes coughed up between sandstorms. They haggled as a pack, spinning tales to puff up the value of their finds. But today was different. Siania, small and quiet, stepped forward and placed a smooth turquoise pebble on the driverâ€™s seat. Light glinted off its deep blue-green surface. The boys exchanged glances. This one was special. Jaro elbowed Tarek. â€œThatâ€™s from the Mage Sands, isnâ€™t it? She actually went there?â€ Envy and respect warred in his voice. The driver let out a low whistle, turning the pebble in his calloused hands. â€œMage Sands, eh? Dangerous ground. Fine piece of turquoise, though. Not many cross those dunes without the sand claiming â€™em.â€ â€œNot worth much,â€ he added, squinting. â€œSee this crack? And itâ€™s barely bigger than a pebble. Pretty, but pretty donâ€™t fill my purse.â€ Jaro leaned in. â€œThatâ€™s not a crackâ€”thatâ€™s a sand-scribeâ€™s line. The desert writes its history into these stones. See how the color pools around the marks? Thatâ€™s the ink of the dunes.â€ The driver snorted. â€œPoetry wonâ€™t pay you, boy. And â€˜smallâ€™ just means less weight for my wagon, and less meat on my plate.â€ Tarek crossed his arms. â€œSmall means it danced through the sinkholes and lived. The Mage Sands chew up the big ones. This little beauty? Itâ€™s clever. Like the fox who brought it.â€ The driver chuckled. â€œSo now cracks are history and small means lucky? You lot could sell sunlight to a desert hawk.â€ Sianiaâ€™s voice was soft but firm. â€œThe sands gave this one up its lucky. You wonâ€™t find anotherâ€”not unless you know where to look.â€ She paused knowingly... â€œAnd who to ask.â€ The driver opened his mouthâ€”but Torren stepped forward, his usual grin gone sharp. He plucked the pebble from the manâ€™s palm and held it up to the light. â€œYou know as well as I do what comes out of the Mage Sandsâ€”when anything comes out at all. This didnâ€™t wash up on some riverbank.â€ He nodded to Siania. â€œOnly reason itâ€™s here instead of buried under ten feet of hungry sand is â€™cause sheâ€™s the only soul who can dance across those wastes and come back richer.â€ A beat of silence. The driverâ€™s eyes gleamed as he weighed Torrenâ€™s words. Then he laughed, slapping his knee. â€œSeems I underestimated what you brought me, eh? I suspect I wouldnâ€™t have the gold to pay for a guide to those cursed sands.â€ He winked fondly at his favorite hucksters. Truthfully, it was a fine stoneâ€”and a monthâ€™s travel from here, where even a halfway interesting rock gained value, since there was nothing like it in the capital. (If he could get back in one piece, that is.) The driver dug into his coat, then jerked a thumb toward his wagon. â€œTell you what, fox-cubâ€”since youâ€™re the one who braved the sands for this, you get a handful of sweets, a story worth twice that pebble, andâ€¦â€ He paused, eyeing the boysâ€™ eager faces, then grinned. â€œEnough practice blades for the lot of youâ€”wooden ones, mind, a couple of slings, and a few small knives. But!â€ He held up a warning finger. â€œShe decides how to split it. Thatâ€™s the rule when one brings the treasure, ainâ€™t it?â€ The boys erupted into hushed excitement. Jaro nudged forward, unable to contain himself. "Fair's fair! We all helped raise the price, didn't we?" His eyes darted to Siania, half-pleading, half-calculating. "That's worth something." Tarek opened his mouthâ€”no doubt to push for moreâ€”but Torren elbowed him hard this time. "I'm just saying," he muttered, rubbing his ribs. The driver chuckled, watching their squabble with amusement. "Her stone, her call. Soâ€”do we have a deal, sand-walker?" His outstretched palm waited, rough with old scars, as Siania studied the offer. (text-colour:#c0975f)[''What do you say, little fox?''] <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[We'll share. -> Siania Shares]]</span> <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[ All mine. -> Siania Keeps]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name) <!--Notification--> { (set: $notificationShowing to true) (set: $timer to 3) (set: $fadeStarted to false) (set: $fadeTimer to 1) (set: $forceRepaint to false) <!-- This empty div anchors our live macro without affecting layout --> <div id="notification-container" style="display: contents;"></div> (live: 1s)[ (if: $timer > 0)[ (set: $timer to $timer - 1) ] (else-if: not $fadeStarted)[ (set: $fadeStarted to true) ] (else-if: $fadeStarted and $fadeTimer > 0)[ (set: $fadeTimer to $fadeTimer - 1) ] (else-if: $fadeStarted and $fadeTimer <= 0)[ (set: $notificationShowing to false) ] (if: $notificationShowing)[ <div id="notification" class="(if: $fadeStarted)[fading] (if: $forceRepaint)[repaint]" style="position: fixed; top: 10px; right: 10px;"> (print: $notificationMessage) </div> ] (else:)[ (stop:) ] ] }<H2>Siania Shares</H2> Siania looked at the slings and swords, then at the boys. Thanks.â€ By the gate, two guards exchanged knowing looks, their quiet chuckles barely audible above the desert wind. Siania beamed, proud to be part of the crew. By the end, the driver couldnâ€™t resist slipping a few extra sweets and lollies their wayâ€”especially for the smallest whoâ€™d just proven she was no ordinary misfit. Torren watched Siania beam, her eyes shining with something new. He'd seen the moment unfold perfectly - the boys' initial hesitation melting into acceptance, the driver's extra kindness, even the guards' quiet approval. Their little group had passed some unspoken test today. As Siania distributed the spoils with careful fairness, the driver caught Torren's eye and gave him the barest nod. It wasn't just about the stones or the sweets anymore. The desert had given them something far more valuable today. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span> (set: $siania_trust_jaro to $siania_trust_jaro + 1) (set: $siania_trust_tarek to $siania_trust_tarek + 1) (set: $siania_trust_torren to $siania_trust_torren + 1) (set: $notificationMessage to "Siania's Generosity Pleases All...") Jaroâ€™s smile faltered, and Tarek looked particularly put out. â€œWe all helped, Siania,â€ Jaro said quietly, â€œbut it seems youâ€™re keeping it all for yourself.â€ Torrenâ€™s grin remained, but it was tinged with something sharperâ€”an unspoken warning. Siania, though a little nervous under their gaze, held her ground. She knew she needed to look out for herself, but the cost was clear. By the end, the driver still slipped a few sweets and lollies their wayâ€”though Sianiaâ€™s share was noticeably smaller. Torren watched her, a thoughtful expression on his face. Heâ€™d seen the boysâ€™ reaction, the way theyâ€™d expected her to share. But Siania had surprised themâ€”and maybe, just maybe, earned a different kind of respect, one born of caution rather than camaraderie. But it wasn't just the boys whose opinions mattered. Siania felt a subtle chill in the air, a hint of disappointment in the gaze of the driver and the guards standing nearby. They expected a certain generosity, a certain grace. Their quiet disapproval was almost imperceptible, but it was there nonetheless. A princess should be generous, selfless, a symbol of hope... and perhaps, she had much to learn. <span class="styled-choice" style="color:#c0975f;">[[Next|Days of Innocence 2]]</span> (set: $notificationMessage to "The boys remain wary. (display: "Notification") (set: $fortKezerakApproval to $fortKezerakApproval - 2) (set: $jaro to $jaro - 1) (set: $tarek to $tarek - 1) (set: $torren to $torren - 1) (set: $loyalistApproval to $loyalistApproval - 1) (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<H2>The Diplomat - A Reckless Gambit</H2> Valerius let a faint edge creep into his smile, holding Lady Vestergaardâ€™s gaze a moment longerâ€”a silent dare to test her composure. The polite veneer between them cracked just enough to reveal the undercurrents of rivalry and threat. Her attendants stiffened, exchanging wary glances. Her sonâ€™s expression flickered with interest, recognizing the boldness but also the risk. He preferred subtlety, but understood the power of a well-timed provocation. A cold wave of self-reproach washed over Valerius. This was not strength; it was a misjudgment. The Countâ€™s son had once traded with House Krenâ€”an alliance now severed. Valerius had needed to secure the sonâ€™s cooperation to forge an alliance vital for the realmâ€™s stability. Now, lacking any real leverage, his reckless challenge had scuttled that possibility. The fragile bonds that kept the border towns supplied with iron and wheatâ€”and thus the realm secureâ€”were imperiled by his error. Worse still, he had invited the wrath of House Vestergaard itself, led by Lady Vestergaard, whose son was soon to marry the Emperorâ€™s daughter and currently enjoyed the emperors favor. The consequences of this misstep would not be easily borne. [[return to sianias trial]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<H2>The Diplomat - A Measured Pause</H2> Valerius returned Lady Vestergaardâ€™s cool appraisal with a polite, unreadable smileâ€”the faintest suggestion of warmth, carefully measured. The court was a game of patience and precision; now was not the time to reveal his hand or risk alienating a powerful house. He needed to preserve the fragile possibility of alliance with the Countâ€™s son, whose cooperation was vital to securing the realmâ€™s borders. He knew the stakes all too well. The border towns depended on the steady flow of iron and wheat, resources controlled by House Vestergaardâ€™s influence. Any misstep could imperil that lifeline. Moreover, Lady Vestergaardâ€™s favor with the Emperor, bolstered by her sonâ€™s impending marriage to the imperial daughter, made her a formidable adversary. Provoking her now would invite retribution that House Kren could ill afford. From his seat, Darian Vestergaardâ€™s eyes flicked between Valerius and his mother. He caught the subtle shift in Valeriusâ€™s expressionâ€”the careful restraint, the measured politeness. His motherâ€™s gaze remained sharp, unreadable, but Darian noted the diplomatâ€™s smooth handling of the moment. No rashness, no challengeâ€”just the quiet calculation of a man who knew the stakes. Darianâ€™s fingers drummed lightly on the armrest, his thoughts unreadable. He said nothing, but the look he gave Valerius was one of cautious acknowledgmentâ€”a silent recognition of a player who understood the courtâ€™s delicate dance. By holding back, Valerius chose prudence over bravado. He would wait, watch, and seek subtler means to rebuild trust and forge the alliance necessary to stabilize the realm. The game was far from over, and patience might yet turn the tide. [[return to sianias trial]] (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name)<H2>Return to the Passing</H2> His gaze snapped back to Siania, then involuntarily to Vestergaard. The Countâ€™s face was rapt. Their bond. If the old bloodâ€™s power was real â€“ and the impossible evidence screamed that it was â€“ then their union wasnâ€™t just a political trap laid by Severin. It was a potential conduit for the very force the Order sought to controlâ€¦ or a spark to ignite that force against them, guided by its own inscrutable purpose. Magic might "use" them, his mentor warned. But to what end? Against Severin? Valeriusâ€™s stomach clenched. Severing the bond felt monstrous, a deeper dive into the moral rot he despised. Yet allowing it under Severin's thumb... was that surrender to the deeper rot he'd failed to defeat? His gaze caught Sianiaâ€™s fleeting glance toward Count Vestergaard. Her betrothal to the count, an arranged bond steeped in political necessity, complicated everything. Their exchanged glancesâ€”tentative, genuine, a rare spark in this court of masksâ€”tightened Valeriusâ€™s chest. Vestergaardâ€™s bribed staff had whispered of his secret hope: despite a lifetime of mistrust, he yearned for Sianiaâ€™s love to be genuine. Valerius, witnessing her unguarded focus on the Count even now, knew it was. Their sincerity, radiant and undeniable, made what he must consider all the more unbearable. Their love was a threat, not because he was cruel, but because the Order of Severin had arranged it. House Vestergaardâ€™s bloodline, though lesser, echoed the old magic. Together, their union could awaken what Severin sought to controlâ€”the very foundations Talon was built uponâ€”. Torn between duty and conscience, Valerius turned his attention back to the arena, but his mind raced. His fingers grazed the list in his sleeve. He could sever their bond. //An â€˜accidentâ€™ befalling the favored Count would disrupt Severinâ€™s plans, potentially cripple the Orderâ€™s hold over the Vestergaard resourcesâ€¦ and, at least, prevent Siania from becoming a conduit for Severin's power. The thought of her as a vessel for that darknessâ€¦ it was a fate too terrible to contemplate.// The thought died as quickly as it formed. //Futile. Severin would simply find another Vestergaardâ€”a cousin, an uncleâ€”someone else of the bloodline to bind to Siania. Killing the Count wouldn't break the potential conduit; it would merely shift the danger onto another pawn, likely one even more firmly under Severinâ€™s thumb. Heâ€™d achieve nothing but Sianiaâ€™s hatred and deepen his own descent into the rot. To destroy something so real for such a hollow victoryâ€¦ it would make him no better than Severin.// The diplomat who had once loved and lost recoiled violently. Duty clashed with the shreds of humanity he clung to, and Valerius clenched his jaw. He hated the choices this court forced upon him. Leverage existed. Vestergaard himself sat conspicuously distant from his motherâ€™s retinue. Valerius knew the Count despised Lady Vestergaardâ€™s ruthless ambition; his own spies spoke of quiet dissent. //He needs Vestergaardâ€™s iron and steel to protect the borders, and he needs the Count himself to lead his house, not his mother. If the union could be prevented â€“ if the dangerous connection was broken without bloodshed â€“ perhaps Vestergaard could be turned. Not killed, butâ€¦ bent. An ally against Severin, a source of vital resources, and a bulwark against his own motherâ€™s machinations.// It was the only path that wasn't ultimately self-defeating. A cold, pragmatic calculation, offering a glimmer of control in the chaos. But it still meant breaking two hearts he now knew were genuine. A necessary sadness, perhaps, but a profound one. His mind, usually so full of lists, remained deliberately open on how to achieve this separation and alliance. The old methods were insufficient. He would need new tools, subtler pressures. The coded list was suddenly pathetic, a map of a world that had just irrevocably changed, a world where the deeper battle required tools far beyond bribes and assassinations. The arenaâ€™s noise receded, replaced by the phantom hum in his tooth and the terrifying whisper of possibility. Magic wasnâ€™t just a rumour; it was here, potent, autonomous, and utterly necessary. House Krenâ€™s careful diplomat stood on the precipice. To cling to the old ways was to guarantee Severin's victory. To embrace the chaos was to risk being burned... but perhaps also to forge something new in the fire. Hope, he realized with a shudder that had nothing to do with the breeze, wasn't just dangerous; it was a leap into the unknown arms of a force that might save them or consume them, according to its own destiny. His fingers tightened on the useless parchment. He didnâ€™t dare call it hope; hope was too fragile. Yet as he watched Siania, something long dormant stirred in himâ€”a sense of purpose he had nearly forgotten. For years, he had settled into the diplomat's role, trading dreams for practicality, binding his house with careful bargains and cold strategy. He had tried, and failed, to root out the courtâ€™s corruption; each attempt cost him friends, allies, pieces of his humanity. The rot always returned, deeper, more insidious, until he stopped believing real change was possible. But Siania was different. She was more than a political assetâ€”she was a symbol, a rallying point that could draw loyalty not just to her, but to the Tirianian cause. Her presence offered a chance to unite the fractured realm, to finally break the cycle of decay. If she succeeded, it would not be through careful bargains, but by inspiring genuine allegiance, and perhaps even faithâ€”something he could never manufacture. Valerius found himself wanting her to winâ€”not just for the advantage, but for the possibility that she could accomplish what he could not. If she could sweep away the Order of Severin, the source of the corruption, perhaps there was hope for the realm, and for the part of himself he feared was already lost. //Let her win, and let there be a path forward that spares us allâ€”.// The possibility unsettled him, bright and unfamiliar. The Solunara cast its twin shadows across the arena, but within Valerius, a spark ignitedâ€”a fragile hope, profound and terrifying, yet perhaps the only light sharp enough to pierce the deeper rot. <span class="utilityBtn"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Author notes: Valerious]]</span> <span class="styled-choice"> (text-colour: "#c0975f")[[Next|Chapter 3 Vestergaard: Thoughts before the fight]]</span> (set: $lastPassage to (passage:)'s name){ <!-- Update Siania's loyalty to Torren --> (set: $siania to $characters's siania) (set: $currentLoyalty to $siania's loyaltyToTorren) (set: $newLoyalty to $currentLoyalty + 10) <!-- Increase loyalty by 10 --> (set: $sianiaUpdated to (datamap: "loyalty", $siania's loyalty, "morality", $siania's morality, "sway", $siania's sway, "loyaltyToTorren", $newLoyalty )) (set: $characters to (datamap: "emperor", $characters's emperor, "ladyVestergaard", $characters's ladyVestergaard, "severin", $characters's severin, "court", $characters's court, "ash", $characters's ash, "vestergaard", $characters's vestergaard, "jaro", $characters's jaro, "tarek", $characters's tarek, "agamar", $characters's agamar, "kaleth", $characters's kaleth, "arafis", $characters's arafis, "valerius", $characters's valerius, "draethlyn", $characters's draethlyn, "KezerakRevolt", $characters's KezerakRevolt, "halak", $characters's halak, "siania", $sianiaUpdated, "torren", $characters's torren )) <!-- Display Siania's current loyalty --> Siania's loyalty to Torren: $sianiaUpdated's loyaltyToTorren <!-- Conditional text based on loyalty --> (if: $sianiaUpdated's loyaltyToTorren < $allyThreshold)[ Siania is not yet your ally. Threatening her would be out of character.<H2>Arrive at carravan</H2> Theyâ€™d crowd around the drivers, slipping a jest pebble into a pocket, pressing bits of desert glass, shiny stones, and odd trinketsâ€”scavenged or â€œborrowedâ€â€”into calloused hands, clamoring for more stories, more sweets, more of anything the world might give. The drivers, dusty and road-weary, were masters of mischief in their own right. With a sly grin and a twinkle in their eye, theyâ€™d spin tales so tantalizing that the children would beg to hear the next partâ€”only to be told, with exaggerated regret, that the stories could only continue once the wagons were unloaded. â€œAh, but the best partâ€™s at the bottom of this crate,â€ a driver might say, patting a heavy chest, â€œand my old bones canâ€™t lift it alone.â€ The children, incorrigible hucksters themselves, recognized the game, but dove in anywayâ€”leading the caravan upto the fort as a dubious honourgard then bartering their labor for each new scrap of adventure, their shouts of â€œmore, more, more!â€ a never-ending payment demanded for their efforts. (if: $helpedSiania)[ The boys kept close to Siania as they mingled with the others, her eyes bright with anticipation now that they had arrived. She had felt alone before, and even if this was only a beginning, it was better than what had been. The boys glanced at her with quiet smiles, impressed by her effort. They watched her out of the corners of their eyesâ€”no longer wary, but not quite sure how to welcome her, either. Their laughter grew a little louder when she drew near, their boasts a touch more extravagant, as if hoping to impress her without seeming too eager. Every so often, one would nudge a shiny stone her way or toss her a sweet with a crooked grin, testing the waters of new friendship. It was clear they wanted her to join in, even if they didnâ€™t yet know how to say so. ](else:)[ Still, Siania lingered at the edges of the group, her small frame and quiet ways making her an uncertain presence among the boys. ] Torren could feel the shiftâ€”how the boys held back, unsure what to make of her. He could keep the best for himself, proving who was in charge; stick close to Siania, letting the others drift; or find a way to pull them all in, weaving her into the game as only he knew how.
